text:
EXCELLENT! 
I would have never in my entire life thought that I'd EVER eat a brussels sprout. They're cute to look at, but OMG the stench of cruciferous veggies cooking just makes me gag. Plus I'm not into "mushy middles" (I think reviewers called it "creamy"). But I did want to try this recipe due to all the rave reviews. And now, I want to THANK the person who posted this fabulous recipe! My husband and I LOVED every morsel! I did do 2 changes: 1- we halved them, so that we wouldn't get "mushy middles", lol. And, I read somewhere that if you remove the "choke" that's at the bottom of the sprout (inside), the brussel sprout will not be bitter. Voila! it worked! These yummmy, salty, nutty, crunchy, carmelized brussel sprouts were SO good. No bitterness whatsoever! The super dark carmelized parts of the roasted bsprouts were the best! LUVVVVV this recipe, and will make over and over again! HUGE thanks!!

text:
Yum! This is my favorite way to make brussels sprouts. I first had them prepared this way at a restaurant in downtown NYC around the corner from where I lived--absolutely addictive, and when I moved from that neighborhood I came up with my own version similar to this recipe. The only difference is that I sprinkle a few cloves of minced garlic on top as the sprouts roast, which is delicious--the roasted garlic is sweet and compliments the sprouts without overpowering them. Also, I usually parboil the sprouts first (for 2 minutes).  This draws out bitterness, and cuts down on roasting time (25 minutes to nicely blackened).

text:
I’ve been a member here for years and have never left a review, but this simple recipe has changed that right now.  I’ve roasted cauliflower before ---have been experimenting with roasting veggies lately, but let me tell you this was better than any roasted vegetable I’ve ever had.  It’s so simple too it’s ridiculous!  I bought a bag of fresh Brussels sprouts.  I took off the ends ---small leaves come off when you take off the ends.  ~Word of advice do NOT omit those small leaves . . . they turn into deliciousness in your mouth.  I cut only the big Brussels sprouts in half, but next time ----I will cut them all in half.  I tossed them and the fallen leaves into a bowl with liberal oil, liberal sea salt and fresh cracked pepper and placed the halves face down on my cookie sheet.  As it’s cooking the small leaves will turn dark and roast first ---don’t be alarmed . . . those will be wonderful.  I took them out of the oven when they were done and tasted a small leaf first.  That’s why I’m writing this.  The concept of roasting is so simple, it’s not really a recipe, but the taste that this vegetable yields . . . it’s at the top of the list of any vegetable I’ve ever had.  We’re carb-free/low carb so I served this with a shoulder roast ----one of the best meals hands down since I can remember.  Hope this review has helped someone out there decide to try it.  Remember ---half all of them face down and toss in those fallen leaves . . . you won’t regret it.

text:
I thought these were mediocre...just edible, and certainly not memorable or great. I did not care for the "mushy" or "creamy" interior others found so appealing, nor the overroasted exterior. Also, I don't know how you could roast these as long as the recipe indicates without making them little burnt charcoal briquettes...15-20 minutes was more like it.  I found the look of them unappealing too--much prefer the bright color of simply steamed or sauteed brussels sprouts. Hubby liked them better than I did, tho' he might have just wanted to be nice. (After all, he did leave most of them on his plate) Final word: Always read the lowest rated reviews as well as the highest.

text:
I was really really surprise about these, I love brussel sprouts and needed a new way to try them. This was the BOMB!!!!. I followed the recipe with the exception of cook time and temp. Make sure you used the kosher salt no other, I could tell it would  make a difference, also I cooked mine on 375 degrees and for 30 mins until they were dark brown not black, they also reheat very well. Give this one a try. Update!!!! I'm hitting the store tonight for fresh brussels sprouts, This recipe is really ADDICTIVED!!!!. I cook these all the time, this time I decided to use the garlic as others have stated as I really love garlic. Let me say they were still good, but I think much better just following the recipe as stated. I still can't get enough!!!.

text:
I've tried braising; I've tried boiling; I've tried sauteing. Roasting, I know now, is by far the best.  I left it in longer than I felt comfortable as I watched some brussels sprouts turn dark brown and a few turned black. I'm glad I did, as the darker ones turned out better, with a complex outside and a soft, melty interior.  (The lighter ones didn't have as good insides.)  A nice combination of sweet and salty, and an easy recipe too.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Roasting veggies always gives them more flavor -- and you don't have to add tons of herbs and spices to get it.  I skipped mixing everything in the bag.  I just scattered them on a baking sheet, drizzled with oil, sprinkled with S&P and tossed with my hands.  I let mine get good and brown and they were sensational.  P.S.  I wholeheartedly disagree with the people who think that the roasting time is too long (there's at least two on the first page, and it doesn't appear that either one of them even tried it.  They both just say it's impossible).  I roasted my sprouts for about forty minutes and they were not mushy inside, they were not overcooked, and they were certainly not "charcoal briquettes."  The recipe clearly states to reduce your oven temperature to prevent burning.  The point of this recipe is to slow-roast your spouts.  That's where the flavor comes from -- the SLOWroasting.

I am a Personal Chef. I am always looking for simple recipes for vegetables that are tasty and really make the vegetables shine. I made this recipe for my clients. I cut the sprouts in half before roasting. I added 3-4 cloves of minced garlic after the sprouts had been roasted.I made sure that the sprouts were a deep, deep brown, almost black.    My client told me her and her husband polished off this dish in one night. She said she could have eaten it by herself for dinner. They absolutely loved this dish and have ordered more! Well, thank you for this recipe! My clients were well pleased and that is what keeps my business going. Thanks again!

text:
i was worried to try these since i had to use frozen because my store didnt have any fresh(out of season). i am glad that i did. i bought a 1 lb bag, left them whole, and didn't bother to thaw. i just snipped off the top of the bag, dumped the olive oil and salt in, secured w/ a twist tie, then tossed to coat in the bag they came in. baked for about 25 mins, while shaking every 5 mins or so, and they turned out perfectly. i will definately make these again. next time i will try to get the fresh again to see if there is a huge difference. i served them w/ potato dumplings and pork medallions w/ dijon sauce(both from this site).

text:
I always hated Brussels sprouts, even after I had grown up and learned how to cook all of the strong flavored vegis I disliked as a child, properly. Until that is, I tried oven roasting Brussels sprouts like this! This method yields a wonderful roasty toasty flavored vegetable with great texture! I usually cut them in half before tossing with oil, salt & pepper, and only roast for 20mins, simple and delicious! If you still dislike Brussels sprouts or have kids who do, try this recipe and I can almost guarantee you'll make converts of anyone and everyone who tries them!

text:
This is THE ABSOLUTE BEST way to prepare brussels sprouts!  I used frozen baby sprouts that I steamed in the microwave for 2 minutes first, then sliced in half.  I roasted them in a mixture of olive oil and butter in a cast iron skillet.  No extra spices, just a little salt and pepper - I will never make them any other way.

text:
Wow, I really went wrong with this recipe. I followed the instructions to cook sprouts to the "darkest brown" and found them to be way, way overdone. They were cooking fast, so I turned down the oven temp early on. Still, they were quite well done in less than the time called for in the recipe. Very lightly roasted, they might have been fine. But cooked according to these directions, I found them to be horribly overcooked. They had an intriguing, nutty flavor that might be ok on its own, but was completely overpowering with my menu of salisbury steak and mashed red potatoes. I'll try roasted brussels sprouts again, using exactly the same technique of tossing with salt, pepper, and olive oil -- but I'll forget the instruction to cook til blackened. Instead, I'll lightly roast and and remove from the oven while they still have some green.

text:
I've been roasting my sprouts (and most every other veggie, too!) for years, and even those who say they hate brussels sprouts like them this way.  It's best in my opinion to cut them in half, drizzle the pan with oil, place the sprouts on the pan, then drizzle them with oil, also.  Kosher salt really does work best, and roast them  until you think they look burned on bottom!  Really!  You want them to be a very, very dark brown.  They are so mild and sweet this way.

text:
Let me start of by saying...I hate brussels sprouts!  I've never liked them, no matter how they were cooked.  My family, on the other hand, loves them.  I'm always looking for new ways to cook them that aren't boring, and decided to try this.  The smell while they were cooking was a little unappealing, to say the least...lol.  When they were finished (and I had to force myself to leave them in the oven while they were getting browner and browner), my hubby talked me into trying a small bite.  WOW!!!  I'm a brussels sprouts convert.  I will eat them made like this any day.  Sorry for the long review, but I was totally shocked at how good these were.  Try them and see for yourself!  *Update* :  Even better with a little garlic powder sprinkled on!

text:
I will never boil another brussel sprout! Roasting is the only way to go. The first time I made them I had that moment of panic as the smoke started, and I was scared I was burning them to death! But be brave and let them roast away! The black ones are definitely the best. I've tried this method now with other vegetables - asparagus and leeks also come out great. Thank you for passing on such a simple but satisfying recipe!

text:
I have been making this recipe ever since i saw it in Ina Gartner's Barefoot Contessa recipe book.  It is simple, healthy and delicious.  Every time I've served it to guests it becomes the way they prepare brussel sprouts from here on out! The key is to not fear the deep brown color (they're still bright and moist on the inside) and to use lots of olive oil and sea salt.

text:
The longer you let this marinade, the better it becomes. I put this whole recipe in a gallon size ziploc bag and left it for about 2 hours. It really makes a difference! The second time I made this, I only marinated for about 30 minutes and the sprouts didn't quite have the same salty, crunchy taste to them as the first batch.

These are absolutely delicious! 400 for 15-20 minutes and shake 'em around a bit (depending on preference-dark brown  and crunchy is best for us).  Oil just to coat and give some shine for crisping/roasting, salt and pepper to taste (we like 'em a bit salty).  YOU CANNOT GO WRONG WITH THESE!

text:
This is a simple and very tasty recipe which succeeds because of the contrasts in textures and flavors.  We loved the contrasts: crunchy, salty outer leaves and creamy, subtley sweet sprouts.  

I used a jelly roll pan (raised edge) and stirred the sprouts with a wooden spoon instead of shaking the pan.  Clean-up was easy.

I will definitely make this again!

text:
I crave these! I made them for Thanksgiving last year and have been making them every few weeks ever since. The first time you make them you will worry that you are burning them, but just have faith because they are supposed to be dark golden brown on the outside and warm and tender on the inside. I use a chunky sea salt and lots of freshly cracked black pepper. Yum! Everyone in my family will eat these, even if they don't typically like brussels sprouts!

text:
These were the bomb! We grew them this year and was tired of steamed with butter. I quartered the largest ones we had to make them cook faster and get more browned areas; tossed with garlic flavored olive oil, Weber seasoned salt and Lawry's seasoned pepper. Spread on foil lined baking sheet - 15 minutes at 400 deg. in the convection oven and they were nicely blackened and tasted out of this world. Even the husband who admitted he isn't that crazy about sprouts LOVED these and wants them again. Wish I had thought to snap a picture before we devoured them!

text:
Brussel sprouts?  YUCK - or so I used to think before making this recipe.  The mere mention of the word Brussels sprouts brought back childhood nightmares of having these at dinner!  Well, if my mom had made them this way I would not have missed on 3 decades of enjoyment!  These are GREAT!  The huba AND all 5 of the kids liked them.  Yeah - a kid approved vegetable!  Imagine!  Dont be afraid to roast them until dark.  That is the best part.  In fact next time I make these I will slice the large ones in half to get move of that roasted flavor in each proportinate bite.  I did add 1 tsp soy sauce, 1 tsp chopped garlic and 3 tbsp Italian salad dressing with a few shakes of crushed red pepper.  Did not change anything else.  Thanks for sharing this great recipe and reintroducing me to sprouts!  Yum!

text:
I put off making this recipe because I couldn't see how it could possibly be better than my normal recipe for brussels sprouts.  Boy, was I wrong.  These smelled so good while cooking that it was all I could do not to open the oven halfway through and devour them all.  But I waited until they were done and it was worth it because they were unbelievably delicious.  They do not resemble in any way the brussels sprouts we all know and hate.  They are crisp and nutty on the outside while the inside just melts away in your mouth.  Crazy but true - these brussels sprouts are better than french fries.

This recipe is so fantastic and simple!  I bought two packages of brussel sprouts from trader joes, cut the grey stems off, halved only the big ones, and threw em in the oven for 35 minutes and they were PERFECT.  The halved brussels were crispy on the cut side, the whole ones were browned on the outside, and the middle was soft but not too soft.  And they're still great as leftovers.  Excellent recipe!

text:
OMG - why have I not eaten brussel sprouts before?  These were wonderful! We halved all the sprouts after cutting off the ends and added butter and a little lemon for tang.  The "charred" sprouts were so very yummy and tasty. One dinner guest who has been eating sprouts his whole life said these were the best he'd ever eaten! We are so excited to have another veggie in our rotation! To help cut down on smell when cooking, set out 1 cup of fresh white vinegar on counter before putting these in oven.  My mom has done this for years with stinky veggies (cabbage/broccoli, etc). and it really works!

text:
We are needing more strictly vegetable recipes, so I was excited to find this one. I used really fresh, young Brussels sprouts, and made it exactly like the recipe, only adding some crushed garlic on top, as suggested in reviews. I literally set the timer for 7 min, and shook the pan/stirred at that interval. After 4 intervals, I roasted another 4-5 minutes. The sprouts were perfect - some outer leaves were crisp, and there was even browning/blackening. Unlike one reviewer, I found the look very appetizing. And the taste was amazing! I doubt I will ever make Brussels sprouts another way anymore. And yes, I went back and bought more sprouts to do again the next day!!

city:

country:
None
text:
These were great!  When i told my husband what I was making, he scrunched up his nose and said cautiously..."whhhhy?".  They were SO good.  My husband was amazed how good they were, and was *disappointed* when they were gone.  I can't believe I made Brussels Sprouts, and that they were good!  This is what i did:  I cut off the bottoms little bit, pealed off the top 1-2 leaves, and cut them in half.  Put them in a plastic bag and tossed with olive oil, S&P.  Put into the oven on some parchment paper, and baked for about 20-25 min on 425-450 degrees.  Turn them 2-3 times while baking.  They're done when they started to darken.  Try one and make sure they're tender before taking them out of the oven.

text:
They were absolutely delicious Jaq, thank you!  I read many reviews and was afraid they would be burnt on the outside and mushy on the inside. I decided to turn the heat down, then up again and I shouldn't do that. The second time I cooked them I followed the directions, although I didn't cook them as long as suggested because I  prefer firmer vegetables. As it turned out, I loved the slightly charred taste. Mine were not mushy, burnt and most of all, not mediocre. Check some of the photos and see how they all look like they are cooked just a little different, according to everyone's personal taste. I will never cook them any other way, unless it would be to cook them on a hot grill. Yum!

None
country:
None
text:
Like others have mentioned, you don't need to roast these near as long as the recipe states.  What I do is cut the sprouts in half, remove the cores/chokes, toss in oil as stated and roast for 10-15 minutes.  At this point you will see the outer leaves starting to brown nicely.  I then use a spoon to smoosh the sprouts which separates them nicely, then go another 10 minutes or so, which allows all of the sprouts to get nicely roasted, not just the outer leaves.  Since there isn't much to this recipe, you can't really mess up any of the details, so I gave it 2 stars.

text:
I LOVE brussell sprouts. this is a wonderful way to make them. But, if you are short on time use all the same ingredients and add sliced shallots. Soften the shallots in oil in skillet on stove top over med. flame. Add in halved brussell sprouts and cover for a few minutes. Add in about 1/4 cup water then cover again for about 2-3 minutes. Remove lid to let any excess moisture evaporate.  PERFECT for when you are in a rush.

text:
These were just perfect!  I never would have thought to make them like this.  Simple and so flavorful!  Only thing I changed was putting them on a pizza pan with a lip on it so they wouldn't roll around.  Thanks so much for sharing.
Christmas 2012 update:  I took a chance cutting kitchen time using 3 bags of frozen, thawed brussel sprouts.  Used the same amount of oil, Kosher salt and 1 t. coarse ground pepper.  I put them in a 9x15" casserole dish in a 375 degree oven so I could serve it right from there.  Set the timer for 10 minutes, shaking the pan back and forth 3 times for a total of 30 minutes.  These are just to die for!

text:
My husband loves brussel sprouts and I ...tolerate... them. This recipe is good even to me, and it is a cinch to make. My oven may run a little hot, plus my husband likes them a little crunchy, but the first time I tried this, I thought they were a little overcooked. So, I did not cook them as long as suggested the second time, maybe 20-25 minutes.  I added a tad more salt and pepper than the recipe, and I definitely turned them every five minutes to avoid burning. They were tasty, and tasty is a word I've never used in reference to brussel sprouts before.

text:
This is the best brussel sprout recipe I have tried. I love the texture, and they are so easy to prepare. I didn't even bother with the plastic bag. I just put the cleaned brussel sprouts in a baking pan, put the oil, salt and pepper on them, tossed them around until they were all coated, and popped them in the oven! They also reheat beautifully in the microwave. Husband loved them too!

text:
THANK YOU to JAQATAC!  These were absolutely delicious!  I loved them!!  I followed the directions EXACTLY, to the letter.

Personally, and this is just my opinion and taste, but 400, for 45 minutes is a bit too long.  I like darkened and a little crispy, but for me, it's a little too crispy.  I will definitely be making these again, for sure!  I'll just do it on a little lower temp, maybe 345 for 30 minutes.  Also, cutting a lemon in half and squirting a bit on these, before baking, adds a subtle zesty kick.  A few sprinkles of parmesan cheese, before baking, also adds a nice taste!  Again, GREAT RECIPE!  I loved it and highly recommend it.  

Beth Wilson
Raleigh, NC

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6654681.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is fantastic.  Simple, easy, non-complicated and it highlights the flavor and texture of really good brussels sprouts.  It doesn't mask their flavor with bacon or other strong flavors.  It's so easy to toss together and pop in the hot oven along with whatever else you're roasting.  Simple and perfect!  

If you don't like brussels sprouts you've probably never had them cooked well and from fresh.  Fresh sprouts, properly trimmed, and cooked like this are a whole different experience than frozen or canned and boiled to smithereens.

Tip:  Do like the directions say and TRIM the woody base off and REMOVE the outer leaves.  Trimming the sprouts really does make a difference!

Followed recipe but after trimming cut brussel sprouts in half and also added 1 teaspoon garlic powder and some thinly sliced onion.   When finished baking seeing the blackened veggies had me in a panic but they weren't burnt tasting at all just nice and crispy on the outside and nice and tender on the inside. ABSOLUTELY DELICIOUS this recipe is a keeper. THANK YOU!

text:
I love cabbage, but never really gave brussel sprouts a fair chance. I made this, and it is my husbands and my new favorite side dish. We are making it for Thanksgiving this year. I use frozen brussels, and I took the advice of others and boiled them for about 5 minutes, and then season them (just in a large bowl, not a resealable bag) and roast them. I haven't gotten a chance to roast them for the full time yet, and I pull them out when my husband gets home so we can eat right away, and he has gotten home earlier than I expected. But I have roasted them for no less than 20 minutes with great results.

text:
I served this tonight and everyone wanted more.  I cut the sprouts in half, crushed 2 cloves of garlic to mix with the olive oil, salt and pepper.  I cooked at 375 for 30 minutes and they turned out perfectly.  The outside leaves were browned and beautifully carmelized and the inside was soft but not mushy.  My fiance was so disappointed that he couldn't have more, and my picky daughter ate all of hers and loved them as well.  We will definitely be making these again and again.  Thank you for a great recipe.

text:
This is a technique I love to do, and is SO YUMMY!  I, however, halve the sprouts, add garlic powder along with salt/pepper, cut back on the oil, and adjust the cook time to 30 minutes at 375 degrees to keep the sprouts from getting too mushy, like other reviewers (I tack on a couple of minutes under the broiler in the end for extra crispies, if needed).  Because of these modifications, I gave it 4 stars...  But it is really a to-die-for way of preparing brussel sprouts (even if you think you don't like them).  Gets rave reviews.

userID:
15414713
Display Name:
dawn,ohio

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614242.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Brussels Sprouts are such a great vegetable and super healthy for you too! I agree that roasted is the best way to go, I have been cooking these for years now.  My changes to them to really have "wow" worthy are as follows.  First, after you trim them slice them in half, they will cook much better this way. Second, swap coarse sea salt for the Kosher salt, I always salt to taste.  I suggest roasting for 30 to 35 min on 375, 400 is a bit high.  Once the Brussels are roasted to your liking, toss them with a bit of masala wine then add a bit of fresh grated good quality white cheddar cheese.  They are phenomenal this way! Oooops, I almost forgot, I also throw in about three garlic cloves for added flavor when roasting.

elttaes

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2215298.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Absolutely delicious! 

I made them as they were the first time and ended up really, really liking them. The caramelization on the outside made these addictive! The second time around, I did a couple of things differently. I blanched them in hot water before shocking them in ice water. Then I halved them so there's more surface area for them to get more caramelization. Not only til then did I coat them in the olive oil, salt and pepper. I only had to broil them in the oven at 425 F for about 10-12 more mins after that and they were perfect.

Also, while they are delicious as they are, they're also delicious with a drizzling of balsamic reduction. So yummy!

text:
I've made Brussels sprouts this way for a couple of years......best discovery ever!  Two things I do differently.  I cut them in half, such that each half has some of the stem end.  This allows more of the surface area to caramelize, which makes them even better!  Adjust the cooking time as needed.  I also skip the step of placing them in a plastic bag.  Instead, I just place them on a big roasting pan, pour on the oil, and toss them right on the pan......works great.

LOVE THIS!  Who would of thought brussel sprouts could actually be good.  I'm not kidding, I crave this recipe!  I've made it 3 times this past month.  SUPER easy.  I use frozen sprouts- right from the bag- no defrosting.  Bake on 350 for about 45-60 minutes.  You really can't overcook them, but I wouldn't pull them out too early.  It's true the darker they are the better!  Also use Kosher salt- I think it makes it better than reg salt.  TRY THESE!!

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I make this exact recipe, however, I cut the Brussels in half before roasting. No need to waste a plastic bag, just use a bowl. 400° is good. Place flat side down on a cookie sheet, parchment is helpful. Once Brussels are deep brown on the bottom, (about 10-12 min) flip them. Roast until soft and brown. (about 10 min) Probably a darker brown then ya might think. Melts in ur mouth. The key is slicing them in half!

text:
These were wonderful!! I have always liked brussel sprouts but was looking for a new way to prepare them and this rocks. I live alone and made this thinking I'd have leftovers but that's not going to happen b/c I ate them all in one sitting. Someone else commented that they had to go out for more sprouts to make them again and if it was more than 12° outside here in Wisconsin, I'd do the same. I did slice them in half, as someone else suggested, and had no problem with "mushy" centers. I do think the cooking time was a little long (but sometimes I think my oven cooks a little hot). They were just brown at 30 mins., but pretty black at 45. OK by me; I like a little char, but next time I may only go with 35-40 mins. Thanks to whoever posted this!

1715010
Display Name:
Danni Skaricki
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/54.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have been making these for a long time. My whole family- kids included- devour them. Even friends who don't like them will eat these. First, this is a great recipe to tweak and make your own though you don't have to- we all have our cooking styles. Feel free, to put on more spices, we love seasoned salt and garlic powder. I also roast garlic in with the sprouts. The main thing, I feel it helps for bitterness, blanch your fresh sprouts in whatever broth you prefer, for about 5 minutes before you roast. I have never had a bitter or mushy sprout with this recipe, I bake for about 30 minutes. So easy , good for you and delicious. Don't try this recipe with frozen sprouts unless you decrease the cook time. Frozen sprouts are almost always mushy. Thanks for sharing- we love it!

text:
Ha... I did this before I even read this recipe (as an experiment). I roast yukon gold potatoes and baby carrots this same way except adding some fresh rosemary, so you can throw them all in the oven together (be sure to line the baking sheet with tin foil for easy cleanup!) and roast away. Then you have an easy, delicious, filling and healthy side to go with most anything or even alone.

 I give 3 stars because the oven time listed is way too long.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My husband and 17 year old don't care for brussels sprouts, so I usually only cook them for myself. I decided to try this recipe and they gobbled them up! A teaspoon of salt sounds like an awful lot to me. Initially I followed the recipe other than the salt. They were delicious. Now I cut mine in half and score the stem end, then mix them with olive oil, garlic powder and onion powder. Once they're on the cookie sheet, I lightly sprinkle them with garlic salt and black pepper. I start with them cut side up, then flip them over halfway through cooking. It takes 20-30 minutes with them cut, depending how big the sprouts are. I love the outer leaves that fall off and get crispy, yum. This recipe is delicious as is, but you can season to your own taste!

userID:

Display Name:
winelight

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3648295.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Just had this tonight. Normally, I just heat frozen Brussels sprouts in the microwave for a quick side of veg. 
But we were already having leftovers so I decided to make this.
Still used the frozen sprouts (1 lb.), thawed them slightly in the microwave for 3 minutes, sliced them in half, placed them on a baking sheet with a liberal glug of olive oil, salt and pepper, mixed it well with my hands and then placed them all flat side down. Roasted them for 40 minutes, turning about halfway through. They got deeply caramelized, dark brown with some blackening and a very crispy outside with a tender inside, sweet, yet salty
and very moist - almost a creamy texture. . The interest was in the texture ~ both crispy and soft at once. Followed the recipe almost exactly, except for the prep. No need to add anything else but what the recipe calls for. For those who don't like things "well-done", lessen the roasting time or lower the temp. But done as instructed, these were just so delicious! My roommate didn't realize they were Brussels sprouts ~ thought they were potatoes at first. He told me to NEVER make them any other way ever again. Excellent recipe.
Thank you!! *Update ~ had them again tonight....just sooooo good!*

text:
Really nice!  I had 18 brussel sprouts I was given that I needed to use & to tell the truth I was a bit sceptical about whether these would be nice & was doing them for the first time ever with company over.  I actually put these in a re-sealable bag with the oil & salt 24 hours before & left in the fridge in the bag.  I then took them out & roasted them in a oven full of other food on 200C for about 30-35 mins.  I had several guests ask me if a had stir-fried them to make them so nice & they couldn't believe I had roasted them.  They also couldn't believe they only had salt, pepper & oil on them - absolutely yummy!  One of my guests said she has only every tasted nice Brussels sprouts once before, but now this makes it twice.

I made this for the first time. Since I was in a hurry (starving), I didn't read the recipe carefully and cut the brussel sprouts in half and then followed the recipe. I subbed expeller-pressed (takes the coconut flavor out) coconut oil for the olive oil. It was awesome!  Way better than cooking them in water. The centers were as done as the outside. Cutting them in half greatly reduced the cook time. This will become a staple recipe for me. Thanks for providing it!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've been told by a chef friend not to season with salt until they're done, that way the salt doesn't pull the moisture out of the sprouts while they're roasting. Other tasty add-ons to this recipe: squeeze fresh lemon juice over them after roasting, drizzle a little balsamic vinegar, sprinkle some fresh parmesan over top. They're delicious with just salt and pepper as well.
Review:
Rating:

None
text:
Yummy. Haven't had brussels sprouts since I could recall, but my mom says I've had them and liked them so maybe I shouldn't be surprised that I liked these?! Anyway, these are definitely best just out of the oven. They lost some of the nice crispness after being refrigerated, although they were still good as leftovers. I made them in a glass dish so that may have affected the time, but I definitely had to bake more than the 15 minutes that some reviews have suggested. Just pay attention based on your pan/oven!

text:
This is a surprisingly easy and yummy way to make brussels sprouts. Let's be honest people, these still taste like a vegetable, but the simple preparation makes them quite bearable. I cut my brussels in half, because I can't handle an entire mouthful at once, and I thought that helped cut down the cook time. My 4 year old daughter would even eat them, as long as there was sufficient salt on her piece. :)

text:
Sprouts accumulate a gas and to avoid this remove the  tough outer leaves and aftr trimming stem cut a X about one sixteenth deep on the stem. I have been roasting sprouts for years with many variations, reduce salt and add some curry powder. In some kitchens the sous chef will steam them for about five minutes before roasting.

These were a big hit on Thanksgiving.  I first fried some center-cut thick-sliced bacon and saved the grease to saute' half of a red onion, half of a spanish onion and one shallot just for a few minutes.  I tossed the bacon and onions with the brussel sprouts (I didn't need to add more olive oil) and roasted them.  It was very delicious.  The dark brown pieces of brussel sprout were so tasty.

text:
Delicious! I roasted them for 15 minutes at 425 as recommended by another user - perfectly roasted! I used sea salt and added a bit more black pepper to taste. I also cut them in half and flipped them over (instead of shaking them around) twice during roasting (at the five minute and ten minute mark). To top them off I sprinkled sliced almonds over the batch before serving. I had "Almond Accents" roasted garlic caesar flavored almond slices on hand for a salad and they worked  well. I will try plain sliced almonds next time but these were yummy if you want more salt and a bit of garlic flavor.

text:
delicious! I'd never had brussel sprouts before. They seem to have a bad rep for being bitter. But these were anything but bitter. They were pleasantly mild and even sweet/creamy in flavor. I made the following changes: quarter/remove the choke, add a sprinkle of garlic powder, par-cooked in the microwave until slightly tender. Then I roasted just to get the color and the carmelization flavor. My husband and I really enjoyed them and will make then again!

userID:
3379349
Display Name:
megaramsey
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
17
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674165.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I LOVE roasted vegetables!  I've been making them for a long time.  In a big bowl I put in chunk cut potatoes, carrots, brussel sprouts (bigger ones cut in half), sweet potatoes or winter squash, fresh small onions (bigger than pearl, smaller than a small regular onion), and I mix it all up with a good drizzling of olive oil and spices (any kind you like, one of my fav's is rosemary and garlic).  I preheat the oven with my ungreased cookie sheet in it, then when the oven is ready, I pour the veggies on the hot sheet and they sizzle, I roast for about 25 minutes, THEN stir (too soon and you'll lose a lot of the browning edges, they'll stick to the pan and the veggies will fall apart when mixing up), once they are set enough, I mix them up and cook another 20-25 mins.  These are a HUGE hit no matter where I take them.  Remember, if you add celery or any tender veggie, put them in about 1/2 way through the cooking process so they aren't over done.  I always cook 2 cookie sheets full, they are great as leftovers to use as a side dish in a second meal later in the week.  And I always chunk cut my veggies, not tiny pieces.  YUM-MEE :o)

text:
Oh my gosh! I have roasted just about every other vegetable out there, but have never tried roasting brussels sprouts. I don't know why, since they are one of my favorites. These were excellent! Like another reviewer, I added some minced garlic and I roasted at 375 degrees for about 30mins - just til nicely browned - not black. I love the way the outer leaves get crispy. It's almost like eating candy, but with a little salty bite to it. My mother and husband, who don't love brussels like I do, raved about these. My husband was even sharing this recipe with the guys he works with in a millwork shop! Thank you for sharing your simple yet delicious recipe, JAQATAC.

text:
People who say they hate brussels sprouts have probably only had them boiled or drenched in some kind of sauce, but for these little guys, the less you do to them the better! I have been sautee-ing b.s.'s for years, but I thought I'd give roasting a try. I followed the recipe, except I like to cut them in half and notch out the tough, cone shaped pithy center with a sharp knife. This makes them bite-sized and reduces cooking time to about 22-25 minutes. Yum!

Since I'm in my 30s,  I decided to take it upon myself to try brussels sprouts for the first time. I used fresh ones. I added one large, thinly-sliced garlic clove to this recipe, keeping the sprouts on top of the garlic while roasting so the garlic wouldn't burn. Slightly bitter taste on the outside may be due to the garlic, but I can't be sure, since I never tasted them before! Left them in for 45 minutes. Had it for a simple lunch, with pasta sprinkled with Parmesan. Pretty good... good enough to give them another go.

country:
None
text:
Who knew brussels sprouts could taste so good? I am 52 and had NEVER touched a brussels sprout until a friend talked me into trying some "roasted" ones from a food truck here in Austin a few years back, and I could not believe they were the same veggie that our sitter had boiled and fed to my unsuspecting toddler sons 20 years ago. Just walking into her house and smelling the stank of boiling brussels sprouts was enough for me to write them off of my veggie list for good. But, call me older and wiser, they are now a frequent go-to, as I try to improve my eating habits and lower my risk of cancer as I age. These make a PERFECT side dish to evening protein. If you've never tried them (like me), give this recipe a try. And then, if you've never had asparagus (that you liked), try the similar recipe where you oil, salt, and pepper it and then put shaved parmesan cheese over it before baking and you'll have TWO awesome, healthy, delicious veggie sides to serve!

userID:
12500379
Display Name:
BCA
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
3
favoritesCount:
37
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1119566.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
When I think of Brussels Sprout I remember the stringy thin veggie I disliked when I was younger.  Then I was at a local venue called Hyde, in Hollywood, and they had these Brussels sprouts on the menu and I laughed... the waitress was saying they were amazing so I tried them, and when they arrived I was shocked to see they were not at all like I remembered.  They were delicious!  Since I already had an All Recipes profile, I knew what my next recipe search would be... Brussels Sprouts, of course!  I found this recipe and decided to get creative with it and here is what I did.  Bought an Organic 3 lb box of Brussels Sprouts from Whole Foods, same measure of salt (kept smaller amount for low sodium), pepper (did not increase amount due to jalapeno and garlic being added), Organic Olive Oil (increased amount to 6 table spoons with larger serving), diced up half a jalapeno and 2 cloves of garlic and mixed them all up in the plastic zip lock bag, let it sit in bag for 10 mins and then placed them on the tin foil lined baking pan.  Had the oven preheated to 400 degrees F (204 C).  Every 5 mins I turned them just like this recipe calls for but learned that 15 minutes, I reduced heat to 325 as they were already brown.  Cooked them for another 10 minutes turning them every 5 minutes and OMG, they are INCREDIBLE!  Not too spicy or garlicky... just the right amount of zing, better than the ones I had at Hyde in Hollywood, probably because I made them with extra Love and Care!  Enjoy!

country:
None
text:
I made this for the first time last weekend. I've made it two more times since then, it's that good! I halved the sprouts which helped some of the outer leaves come off in the roasting process, and cooked them at 400 for about 40 or 45 minutes, stirring every eight minutes or so. You definitely want some of the loose outer leaves in there because those are the best part! You want them dark and crunchy, they will look burned but they are so good. I added garlic once and it was good but not necessary.

text:
This is a great recipe!  I had never served brussels sprouts until I tried these and now they are a tradition in our family for every party, especially Thanksgiving and St. Patrick's Day.  Time needed for cooking depends on the size of the brussels sprouts.  I always cut mine in half so the outer leaves are crusty (like potato chips!) and the insides are so deliciously soft. I sometimes use garlis salt. We serve them as an appetizer.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
If you're going to make Brussels sprouts, this is the way to do it!  The easier way to go, is to get a deep casserole dish, forget the plastic bag, just put in the oil and Brussels sprouts and stir well, adding the salt and pepper after they are well coated.  Then, every 10 minutes or so, stir them again.  A little trick I learned, when they are done, turn the oven off and leave them sit in there until they cool down a little, if you have the time.  This will give them a nice brown color all over, and a really delicious flavor!

These were amazing. I finally got my husband to try Brussels sprouts, and he was not disappointed! As written, the cook time is far too long. I took other reviewer's suggestions - I cut them in half and baked at 425 degrees for 8 minutes. Then I flipped them and cooked at 400 degrees for another 8 minutes. They were perfectly done. The crispy brown-black outsides definitely made this dish! We will make this over and over again.

text:
I make these pretty much the same way, but I add minced garlic and (if I have it on hand) chopped bacon as well. I usually roast them on 500 for about ten minutes in the beginning, then reduce the heat to 400. I also cover the sprouts with tin foil, take them out and shake them around every ten minutes or so, and in the last ten minutes of cooking will remove the tin foil top to let them brown a bit more. I'd give five stars if I didn't make some minor additions/adjustments to the existing recipe.

Really good!  We debated 4 vs 5 stars.

If you want green sprouts, like what's shown in the picture above, you'll need to roast less time (and what's the point of that??).

Michelle Roth-Kiva

photo:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Delicious and SUPER easy! I've had my eye on this recipe for some time. I can't BELIEVE I waited so long to try it!!! Being that I am the only one who likes brussel sprouts in my family, I made these for myself. All I can say is WOW! Other than scaling everything slightly (my grocer doesn't sell brussel sprouts in bulk so I had to purchase a 1 lb. bag of them) and adding a little more EVOO / seasoning than called for, I made no changes. I used my stoneware jellyroll pan to roast everything in and think this worked very well (there was plenty of room to flip my brussel sprouts for even browning). It took 28 minutes (i.e. 4 intervals of 7 minutes) for my sprouts to cook to a beautiful, golden brown color. They were slightly sweet, a bit soft (but not mushy) and perfectly roasted! Not wanting to waste the leaves, I roasted them as well, and while they were not bad, I could do without them next time. NOTE: Be sure to cut off the stem end of your sprouts and remove the outer, yellow leaves (both impart bitterness). I also find that cutting the larger sprouts in half ensures even cooking... otherwise, your small ones will overcook while your larger ones will be just right. :) Thanks for sharing, JAQATAC. These were the BOMB! :-)

text:
This recipe was a big hit with my wife who "doesn't like Brussels sprouts."   On my second attempt, I cut back on the salt a little, which I liked better.

TIP:  Buy your sprouts still on the stalk if at all possible.  I'm not a "fresh freak" about everything, but I've found there is a big difference with sprouts.  They are not easy to find on the stalk, but if you have a Trader Joe's in your area, they often carry them in that form.  "Fresh" but not still on the stalk, they aren't as sweet and a little bitter.  Frozen, forget about it, you'll have a soggy mess.

userID:
5344877
Display Name:
SleepingUgly

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love brussels sprouts---especially the cuteness factor---and was thinking of trying this for Thanksgiving. Last night, I decided to do a test run, and didn't really care for it, even though I also love things that are salty and crunchy. I found them overcooked, although I took them out after 30 minutes. I think even if I'd cooked them for a shorter time at higher heat, it wouldn't have appealed to me. I'm glad others like it, though.

BTW-I think one of the reasons people don't like b-sprouts is that to cook them through, they have to be cooked too long. To address this, I usually halve or quarter the little dears and steam them only briefly until they turn a beautiful green. Another option is to cut an X into them from the bottom so the heat can get into them. This preserves the shape, if you want, while allowing them to cook quickly. 

I found a recipe in a ladies' magazine many years ago that's another great option for making b-sprout lovers out of former haters. I don't remember the exact proportions, but here's the gist: Cook a bunch of bacon (1/2 lb?) until crisp. Crumble the bacon and save the drippings. Slice up or chop a red onion.  Cook the onion s-l-o-w-l-y in the bacon fat until the onion caramelizes. Meanwhile, steam some b-sprouts until bright green. Stir in the sprouts into the onion mixture until just heated through, then add the crumbled bacon, season to taste, and serve. (Maybe caraway seeds in it, too?) Very festive, and, to me, irresistible.

text:
I absolutely adore this recipe, but like most others, I tweak it a bit.  Used about 1 T olive oil, then another 2 T of melted butter, added 1 T garlic powder, 3 T white wine, 2 T spicy brown mustard, then the salt, pepper, and a dash of white wine vinegar.  I'm sure it's delicious with just the 3 ingredients, but mine were spectacular.  I also cooked them less than the time indicated, and they still turned out nice and brown/ caramelized.

text:
I have to start by saying I did not do the original recipe.  I had the steam bag brussel sprouts.  I steamed them in the microwave for half the time while the oven was heating up.  Took them out, opened the bag and seasoned them per this recipe. Put them in the oven for a few minutes to broil and get roasted and caramel colored.  They were easy and delicious and much easier than dealing with fresh sprouts especially when they are not in season.  I will try them fresh, but this is a great recipe and works well on the frozen steamed bag veggies.
Review:
Rating:

dateLastModified:

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/834241.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Shockingly delicious. This recipe offered a great middle ground between soft insides and still firm sprouts. I did edit the recipe a tad. I cut the bottoms off the sprouts enough that the small outside leaves fell off then I cut the whole sprout in half. Those crispy little baby leaves were my favorite part! Instead of 400 degrees, I did mine at 350 for 20 minutes. The smaller sprouts turned out tender with a nice roasted outside, and the bigger srpouts kept their beautiful green color held a little more firmness. All in all, this is by far my favorite way to cook brussels sprouts! Even if you don't normally like brussels sprouts, give this recipe a try; it won't disappoint!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love this recipe!  I love brussel sprouts roasted better than boiled.  When I want more variety, I add chunks of butternut squash, sweet potatoes, carrots, apples, etc. and bake it altogether with the olive oil, salt and pepper in the oven on a cookie sheet.  Makes a very healthy vegetarian dinner or side dish.    Once you start cooking with fresh vegetables, you won't want to go back to those frozen overcooked plastic microwave in the bags which are so unhealthy for you.  Those bags are convenient, but peeling some fresh vegetables and roasting them, you will be glad that you did because the flavor is so much better.

Very good, simple.  we make these all the time and the family never gets tired of them.  I think the kosher salt is a must - not table salt.  I will sometimes add a few slices of chopped bacon to give it a smoky favor ( may want to reduce oil or add cooked bacon near the end of the cooking time).   Sometimes I will add a clove of chopped garlic.     I just love this simple recipe!

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674145.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is one of my favorite veggie recipes. I roast them for only 20-30 minutes, though -- the charring that occurs is really yummy, but you don't want them to totally burn or turn to mush. I also usually cut the sprouts in half...sometimes they're really big. Definitely keep your eye on them and shake the pan or stir them around a bit every 10 minutes.  For some real fun, throw in a little garlic powder, Adobo seasoning, cumin, or other favorite spices. I've also made this with whole cloves of garlic and cherry or grape tomatoes tossed in. The tomatoes pop open and make a nice little sauce. The garlic turns nice and soft and sweet. And the smell while it's cooking will drive you nuts!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2010-01-06T23:34:40.367

userID:
3157792
Display Name:
Jennifer Hurst
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6852537.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These were amazing! I love the ease and simplicity of roasted vegetables, but I had no idea brussels sprouts would carmelize so beautifully. The only thing I did differently was to use California style garlic salt because I didn't have any kosher salt. I didn't set the timer on the oven and I actually left them in ten minutes longer than I originally intended - they were very dark and charred-looking and I thought I'd overcooked them but the crispy little outer leaves were the best part! I didn't mind the mushy insides but I think next time I would halve them just to get more of that delicious blackened crispiness. I literally ate every last little charred bit that was left in the pan! Thank you for this incredibly easy and delicious recipe!

country:

text:
I HATE Brussels Sprouts so having said that I was at Whole Foods in Portland, ME last month and walked into the prepared foods section when they were giving sample tastings of roasted Brussels Sprouts. I was hesitant at first but after I tasted it, no joke I was won over. So I decided to try this recipe out to see if I could replicate what I tasted. I did, this recipe is fool-proof and now I can say that thanks to this recipe I finally found a way to enjoy Brussels Sprouts!  Update!: If you love garlic try this, take a spoonful of garlic paste (you can buy it ready made at the Indian grocer's or make it at home by putting fresh cloves of peeled garlic in the blender and a bit of water), a few rashers or bacon which have been cut into teeny tiny pieces  and mix it with everything else in the ziplock bag - Heaven!

text:
I have never been a fan of brussel sprouts, but my husband loves them.  After using this recipe, though, I buy them as often as I can and prepare them this way.  Be sure to adjust the quantity of olive oil, salt and pepper if using a smaller amount of sprouts.  I buy one package (9 oz) and reduce oil to 1 T, salt to 1/2 tsp and pepper to 1/4 or so.  Very tasty!!!

text:
I've never eaten brussels sprouts before, so after reading some of the reviews I cut some in half and left others whole.  The soft insides of the whole ones didn't bother or wow me.  The ones that I'd cut in half had more of the carmelized flavor, and were easier to eat because of the smaller size, so in the future I'll probably cut them all in half.  I also shook a clove's worth of minced garlic with the oil, salt, and pepper.  I didn't have kosher salt, so I used regular, and it was fine, but given that some folks have sworn by the kosher, I'll try that in the future to see if I can taste the difference.

text:
I'm on the fence.  I liked these better the next day, cold.  Mine were perfectly dark, almost black.  I liked the carmelized outside and the slightly sweet, creamy middle.  It made for a unique combination.  I would not characterize them as mushy as some reviewers did, just creamy.  They are simple as pie to make, but boy did my kitchen smoke up every time I opened the oven door to shake the pan.  My husband only picked at them, so I probably wouldn't make them again, but I can see why lots of folks loved them.

text:
There is no way to make a mistake with this one! Instead of a bag, I put the ingredients in a tupperware and shook it around.  I did 357 degrees instead of 400 degrees for 1/2 pound of brussel sprouts, and it took 30 minutes. I did some of them whole and some split in half.  I like the ones cut in half better because you get more of that nice carmelized/burnt taste. I also didn't have any kosher salt, so used sea salt which worked fine. I am not a kitchen person and these turned out great!

This was a very easy and delicious side dish. You have to watch it carefully because it does tend to burn the stray leaves that are in the pan. I didn't have to cook it as long as it suggested. I do this same thing with winter veggies, red onions, cauliflower, eggplant, broccoli, squash and peppers...mix together with a little oil, sea salt and pepper and then bake. Turn every 15 mins. or so. Delicious

text:
My friend, Lin, told me about this recipe for roasted brussels sprouts.  She said it was delicious and boy, was she ever right!  These were divine!  My husband was all ready to hate these as he is not a brussels sprout fan.  He gobbled them right up.  I had a theme going with tonight's dinner: blackened catfish and these "blackened" brussels sprouts.  I roasted them at 375 degrees for 30 minutes, and I did sprinkle them with garlic powder with about 10 minutes to go.  If you always thought you hated brussels sprouts, give this recipe a go....you will be surprised, trust me!

text:
Brussels Sprouts taste GREAT this way!! I love the texture of them when they are roasted, too. I used regular salt (because I didn't have kosher salt) and also mixed in a few cloves of sliced fresh garlic (as another reviewer suggested). I tossed the ingredients directly in the baking dish, instead of in a plastic bag. The sprouts came out great! Soooo tasty and tender and full of flavor. I am going to share this method with others in my family who aren't keen on Brussels Sprouts, yet, because I think it's because they haven't tried them roasted. Thanks for the recipe!! We really enjoyed it!

text:
Very good! This was only the second time I have had brussel sprouts and I thought this was very good. I took the suggestion of another reviewer and cut them into quarters and cooked them for a shorter time. I also ended up having to stir them pretty frequently so that they weren't shriveled up burnt. I added 3 cloves of chopped garlic to the pan during roasting, I also did add a little extra kosher salt at the end as well as a little smart squeeze (butter substitute to keep it as healthy as possible), a little lemon juice, and a little garlic paste. These brussel sprouts were tender and roasted at the same time. Thanks!

text:
I've NEVER liked brussels sprouts....HATED them no matter how they were cooked. I'm amazed that this one recipe clicked - loved it. I grew up with mom's burnt toast - so I like the charred effect this recipe provides. I read a LOT of different brussels sprout recipes plus nearly all the reviews for this recipe: I followed some suggestions and used both butter and EVOO, kosher salt, coarse ground pepper. I had clarified butter to dip the sprouts into once cooked, but didn't need it. Just be aware of the charring factor - a taste I really love, but not for everyone.

text:
There's a trick to this recipe. I sliced approx. 10 sprouts in half lengthwise and added a fair amount of salt, pepper and olive oil in a freezer bag. They cooked in about 30 minutes at 200 Degrees Celcius and were PERFECT! I mean they tasted like potato chips! My younger brother said they were very salty and because I ate them all the first time around, I made more with less salt, less pepper,less oil. What a mistake. They were still lovely, but the best way to enjoy these is to make sure they are well salted to taste, with pepper and enough oil. Cook for less time and not so hot. Delicious. By the way, did I mention I ate like a kilogram of these? LOL.

text:
Looking for a side dish that is concurrently easy and delicious?  Roasted Brussels Sprouts is the ticket.  Wow, who knew that vegetables could taste so good.  After preparing this, I can now proclaim that brussels sprouts are the most underrated vegetable in town.  I prefer fresh when possible, but I used frozen today--and they were excellent.  Here's a tip that some folks might find  useful: I used a large bowl instead of a resealable plastic bag.  The bowl process worked clean and smooth for me--better than I imagined the bag might be.  I just poured the olive oil and kosher salt into the bowl and worked the sprouts with my hands.  


Enjoy!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wow, really a simple recipe, but with delicious results.  As others have done, I cut the bottoms off, then cut each sprout in half. In a ziplock, I placed 3 T EVOO -- but 1/2 Garlic EVOO. Added sea salt and freshly ground pepper -- mixed it up a bit, then dumped in the sprouts. I actually let them "marinate" while I was prepping other items for dinner. Then I sprayed a baking sheet with Pam and placed each sprout cut-side down (a must). Roasted them for 1/2 hour  -- and they were beautifully caramelized, extra crispy top skins and totally delicious. Thank you JAQATAC!

text:
This is a great recipe, but please do not follow step #2 to "place  in a large resealable plastic bag. Seal tightly, and shake to coat." You can do this in any large bowl and stir with a wooden spoon to coat. With the large issues we have in this country with plastic overuse, using a large plastic bag to do this task is simply not necessary. Reduce, reuse, recycle!!!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I crave this recipe!  I love how easy it is to make, and I've made it probably a dozen times.  I keep a stock pile of Brussels sprouts on hand at all times for when a craving strikes!  I like to let it cook in the background while I make the rest of the meal.

I slice the Brussels sprouts in half and cook them at 475 instead of 400 in a 13 x 9 Pyrex dish, covering with tin foil to help keep them moist.  Like the recipe says, I shake the dish every 5 to 7 minutes and wait until they are brown with a bit of black on the outside.  My husband loves it.  I love it.  Two big thumbs up.

text:
Yummy, yummy, yummy!   I had a pound of frozen brussels sprouts (eight servings according to the package) on hand; I didn't change any of the ingredients except that I didn't use any pepper.  I sprinkled some nutritional yeast on top of the brussels sprouts then popped it into the convection oven. I baked them at 380°F for 40-45 min.  Perfect!  My husband said that the brussels sprouts are not bad; they're different.  He's never really been a fan of brussels sprouts but he liked this recipe.  The brussels sprouts went well with the fried chicken, noodles, and the pan gravy made from the leftover olive oil and pan drippings.

text:
I have never made or eaten Brussel Sprouts before, mostly because of their bad rep. I bought a pack of fresh halved sprouts, washed them and dumped them in a gallon bag, followed directions and BAM! They were done, and so surprisingly good! Sweet, nutty, soft, warm... a great fall side. The only reason I probably won’t make these again is because the sprouts apparently attract some serious worms. I cut out a ton of bad spots and found some uninvited guests for dinner. I recommend you get halved sprouts so you can see inside before you cook.

country:
None
text:
I was super excited to try this recipe. My mouth watered just reading the reviews. I cut the brussel sprouts in half as the thought of soft middles was not appealing to me. I placed in the oven for 30 minutes. I resisted taking them out early despite them getting blacker and blacker. When my husband first saw them he gave me a snicker. I told him, "just wait, they are supposed to taste awesome." My kids looked at me like I was crazy placing a plate with what looked like little black chars on their plate. Everyone tried them and everyone agreed- thumbs down. Husband said the flavor was o.k. but he just couldn't get over the burnt texture. I wanted to like it, but it was a thumbs down from my three kids and husband.

I've made this recipe many times over the years. I empty two frozen bags of brussel sprouts into a Ziploc bag, coat with olive oil, salt, and pepper. I've shared this recipe with many friends. It's perfect!

OMG I cannot get enough of these. From someone who isn't a huge fan of brussels sprouts, I have to say, it's because every other time I've had them they've been made WRONG. The only thing I did different was cut the brussels in half, chop the bottoms off (to reduce bitterness), and add a clove of minced garlic. So so so good and they store so well! I meal prep for the week and these did not lose any flavour by the end of the week. I highly recommend.

text:
These were delicious! I made one change: cut the sprouts in half and baked them for 25-30 minutes at 400 degrees. They  came out still mostly green with some brown spots and perfect texture - crispy outside and soft inside, but not mushy. The best part were the outside leaves that came off in the bag and cooked to delicious crispy brown flakes. So good! I can't imagine cooking them to be all brown/almost black though - that seems like they would get too burnt. I thought they were perfect with the alteration.

First off let me say that I don't like Brussels sprouts, but I am trying to eat healthier so I wanted to try this recipe as a way to get some good healthy veggies into my diet.  Eating these little guys any other way would be a no star or 1 star so this getting a three star from me is huge.  I did add a splash of balsamic vinegar and a dash of red pepper flakes which I think added even more to these little guys.  I cooked the full 40 minutes turning about every 8-10 minutes and about half way though reduced the temp to 350 to finish up.  I will be making this again as it is a good way to get some healthy veggies in your diet and for Brussels sprouts they were tasty.

I think this is a solid recipe with a few tweaks: 

1. I lowered the bake time from 45 mins to 25 mins. This allowed for the brussel sprouts to roast without being burnt or brown.

2. I cut them in half and baked them face down.

3. I added about 1 teaspoon of red pepper flakes to add a bit of a kick in the flavor

text:
Love this recipe.  Of course because I am on a sodium reduced diet, I simply don't add any salt.  I also keep a bread bag on hand to make these.  I pop them in a bread bag with olive oil to do the shaking part.  Sometimes I put pepper on them before roasting, and sometimes not.  They are delicious both ways,  I couldn't believe how sweet they are. They are NOTHING like the yucky boiled brussels sprouts that nearly everyone hates.  :-)

text:
First time I made these I made them as recipe instructed but I cut the sprouts in to halves. They came out borderline burnt but the ones that weren't were extremely good. I thought they tasted so good that I should just work on tweaking the cooking time and temp. The third time I made them was the charm. I cooked them at 375 for approximately 15-20 minutes. That's what worked for me. I also added golden raisins and walnuts for the last 5 or 6 minutes of roasting. I absolutely love brussel sprouts made this way. So delicious!

I was so skeptical because I usually like a honey glaze or mustard, etc. on my roasted brussel sprouts. These were so simple and easy to make, didn't require pre-boiling and came out perfectly roasted in about 35-40 mins. Make sure to shake the tray every 5-10 mins or so as instructed to ensure even browning. They are delicious!

text:
Super simple.  Super tasty.  Caution:  Don't taste for seasoning until ready to serve.  Otherwise you'll keep tasting them and they'll never make it to the table!!

Tip: Lining your sheet pan with foil makes for easier clean up, however if you use stoneware or bare sheet pan, you'll get a crisper and more roasted bottom.  It'll be worth the extra dish to wash.

I like Brussels Sprouts any way I can get them.  But this is my go-to recipe.  I cook them for 30 minutes starting at 375.  I shake the pan every 10 minutes to roll them around and reduce the temperature 10 degrees each time.  Thats what works for my oven for the perfect sprouts for my family.

helpfulCount:

userID:
7249820
Display Name:
LodiLass
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
16
favoritesCount:
412
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674155.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Weather too hot to roast in oven, so cut them in half and tossed them together with olive oil, sea salt, and about 6 whole cloves of peeled garlic.  Put in pie tin, and roasted over 2 right grill burners at lowest setting for 15 min @ approx 350 degrees.  (Left 2 burners on med.)  Grill cover closed.  Stir every 5 min or so.  After 15 min, put my steaks on the 2 left med burners.  Took steaks off after 8 min, left veggies in covered grill over low heat another 5 min while steaks rested.

Made a reduction of 1/4 c balsamic vinegar & 1 T. Sherry.  YUMMY over brussels sprouts and the whole garlic cloves!!!

My Brussels sprouts were tender, browned but NOT burnt, some more brown than others.  (Even my PICKY son loved it!)  Key is keeping an eye on the roasting, until tenderness is where you want it.  This is a great option to heating up the house when weather is still warm out.

text:
Like other reviewers, I too baked these at 425 degrees for only 15 minutes and they turned out wonderfully!  I kept the oil and seasoning the same and just rolled the sprouts around on a bowl with them before pouring them out onto a baking sheet. To ensure even cooking, I took the "lazy approach" and just baked them for 7-1/2 min on the middle rack and then switched them to the bottom rack for the other 7-1/2 min.  Terrific taste!

text:
I was very surprised at how good these were using so few ingredients. I did use frozen sprouts and partially defrosted them (in their packaging just left them in the sink)I did end up cooking them longer 45 minutes and then another 15 lowering the oven to 300 since the hubby was home later than expected. They were not mushy as you would expect and can only attribute them to their partially frozen state. Hope this extra info helps someone out there.

text:
This is one of my favorite vegetables to roast and this was a great recipe find.  I did change the oil to either grapeseed or avocado; they are high heat oils and it brings the flavor of the brussel sprouts even more. 
UPDATE: My favorite side dish to make but this time I roasted a bulb of garlic along side of the brussel sprouts. When they were done, I took the roasted garlic (after discarding the skins) and combined the garlic & sprouts.  Just before serving, drizzled balsamic glaze (Monini) all over the top while steaming hot...WOW!

None
country:
None
text:
I always read the reviews before choosing a recipe (that's what I love about allrecipes!). The only thing I did differently the first time I used this recipe was to add some minced garlic. I was concerned about the baking time due to some of the reviews, but we loved the results! At 30 minutes I checked the color and ended up leaving the sprouts in for about 8 more minutes to get those dark, roasted markings. They were not overcooked, in fact, they still had some nice fresh green color. Great recipe! Just use your own judgment and check the color, pulling them out sooner if necessary. They are great hot or room temp, so no worries about timing with the rest of the meal.

I've always eaten brussel sprouts, but never loved them, until now!  

The browner they are, the tastier they are!! Don't throw those little leaves that fall off out.  They turn dark brown and become crispy like potato chips and those are the best part of the dish.  My husband & I fight over who's going to get them.

Thanks for posting this recipe.  It's quick, easy & delicious.

text:
Just as good as what they serve in fine restaurants.  Crispy on the outside, but still soft on the inside. I browned them the full 45 minutes.  I thought the shaking every 5-7 minutes would be annoying, but it only takes a second and you don't have to take them out of the oven.  My husband is not a huge fan of brussels sprouts, but he went back for seconds!  I prefer it with regular fine sea salt, not kosher salt. It didn't get as crispy on the outside with the kosher salt.

None
text:
Excellent. I have a friend who hates cabbage with a passion and calls brussel sprouts "baby cabbages". When I made these at first he refused to eat them, then relented and in the end said "Hey, these aren't bad". Tweaked a little: 1) Cut them in half 2) Used some garlic powder 3) Baked on parchment paper/cookie sheet and mid way through, placed another cookie sheet on top and flipped the whole thing. 4) Bake until golden brown, not black. They came our a little crunchy and very flavorful.

None
country:
None
text:
This is a good, basic, how-to-roast brussel sprouts recipe which was exactly what I was looking for.  I wanted to combine asparagus and the brussel sprouts for a veggie melange for dinner one night.  Sometimes one veggie offering is boring--a mixture can add interest.  What I did though to speed up the roasting time was to cut the sprouts in half and then proceeded with the recipe as written.  Because they were cut in half, the roasting time was only 20 minutes (and I added the asparagus, also drizzled with olive oil, s & p at the 10 minute mark for another 10 minutes).

country:
None
text:
WOW!! After reading several reviews I wanted to stay as true to the recipe so I could compare, but I did change a couple things. I only set the oven to 400 degrees only because of something else I cooked that required that temp. I parbroiled the cut halves of fresh brussel sprouts (and leaves that fell off)  for about a min if that, let them cool a tad in strainer.. oiled a baking pan, placed them cut side down, sprinkled leaves all over and then added oven-baked (not totally cooked) pieces of bacon. YUM! Sprinkled on some sea salt. Cooked for 15 mins, stirred it up a little and cooked for another 15 mins. WOW!! That about sums it up. Try it!

The only thing this recipe is missing is LEMON JUICE. Trust me. It makes it even more delicious. Garlic is a great addition as well. I love the use of kosher salt in this recipe. As for the time in the oven: it just depends on the kind you are using. When using the large sprouts fresh off the stalk, 30 to 45 minutes is perfect. I used frozen sprouts this time, the kind that comes in little cardboard boxes in the frozen section. It took a bit longer than 45 minutes, even though the sprouts were small. It is definitely worth it to cook it long enough to brown a bit, as it develops a caramel-like flavor. It's worth making more than you will eat because it's especially delicious when cold! It's a delicious side dish and the leftovers are a great healthy snack.

text:
This is my favorite way to eat brussels sprouts.  It is like eating little garlic wonders of love!  I prefer to blanch my brussels sprouts in salted water first for 1-2 minutes and then roast in the oven.  I find it cuts the cooking time in half and ensure the brussels sprouts are cooked through.  It also helps to eliminate any bitterness.  I do the same thing with broccoli and cauliflower.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
These were delicious.  I skipped the plastic bag step and just put 1 tbsp oil in the pan with the sprouts.  If the pan is sufficiently roomy, the sprouts get coated with oil easily as they roll around when you shake the pan.  Then I lift one edge of the pan and roll them all to one side for a thorough salt & peppering before I shake the pan again to spread them out and then pop them in the oven.  If you'd like to use bacon drippings or another solid fat instead of olive oil, just add it to the pan in the oven while you preheat.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
After trimming the outer leaves, cutting the bottoms off and slicing them in half, I soaked my sprouts in a bowl of salted water for an hour (I'd heard this is helpful removing some of the bitterness associated with brussels sprouts). I then parboiled them for a couple minutes, strained the water out and made sure they were dry. Tossed in a few splashes of garlic-infused olive oil, sprinkling of sea salt and freshly ground black pepper, these were great! I roasted them on a baking sheet lined with parchment paper, cut sides down, so the outer leaves would get crispy and carmelized. I popped them in along with my stuffing that was already baking at 325. The leaves still browned and crisped up nicely after 20 minutes. I'll continue roasting my sprouts instead of any other method of preparation.

text:
My friend is not a vegetable person, but she actually said she couldn't believe how good these tasted. If you knew her track record with veggies, you would understand how monumental that comment was. I just tossed the sprouts with a few drizzles of olive oil right in the pan, and roasted them for 20 minutes because I prefer them only mildly browned. If you cut them in half, you get more surface area for things to get roasty and delicious. I also put some shredded parmesan on top, which got all crispy... definitely the best way to make these!

Wow! These were actually really good. I remember trying brussels sprouts when I was young and absolutely hating them. Now I think I'll be making them pretty often. My Dad picked up a giant stalk of the things on his annual grocery visit, and I wasn't very enthusiastic about them. I decided to try this recipe and I'm very glad I did. I added two cloves minced garlic, a slice of bacon crumbled into pieces, and roasted them for exactly a half hour, shaking them pretty often. My Dad and my brother liked them very much and so did I. text:
Never had brussels sprouts before and had always seen the typical shows of kids dipicting them as gross and disgusting. But my four year old saw them in a grocery store and said she wanted to try them. We try to encourage her to try new things and if she sees something she would like to try we get it. From common fruits and veggies to stuff we have never tried or in some cases even heard of if she asks we get them and try to learn how to eat them. So I bought half a pound and proceeded to hunt up a quick and easy recipe. I happened upon this one and the review to cut them in half and now I'm hooked. My whole family loves them! I can never make enough and there are never leftovers! Even if you hate brussels sprouts I would reccomend giving this a try! I hate mushy veggies a toothless person could eat. So I always take mine out when they are just getting tender but still have a little curnch to them. Great recipe! Thanks so much for sharing it!

country:

text:
I have never been a fan of Brussels sprouts but I really love this version.  I cut the stems off and cut in half then added a medium sized clove of garlic as suggested by other reviewers.  Also cut in half to ensure they cooked through.   I baked at 400 for 15 minutes then shook and cooked about 5 more minutes.    Could have maybe cooked a few minutes longer as the burnt looking pieces were surprisingly the best.  I think they would have been better with a little shaved parmesan on top - will try that next time.   A great way to prepare these!

text:
So delicious!  I've never been a fan of Brussels sprouts because, well, they're bitter and gross. Even with all the butter in the world, my boiled or microwaved sprouts had to be choked down. I had no idea that ROASTING really makes that big of a difference!! I followed the advice of another reviewer and "cored" the sprouts (which I think means cutting out the little thing in the middle/center on each one), and it seemed to make a real difference. I will definitely be making these again! Thanks!!

text:
I was inspired by Top Chef.  One of the chef roasted brussel sprouts.  It looked delicious and he won the challenge.  I needed to incorporate more veggies into my diet and decided, why not?  This is an excellent way to cook brussel sprouts.  Add the minced garlic as a reviewer had suggested, and sea salt or kosher salt makes the difference.  I was worried about the browning but it really does give it an overall great flavor.  I also went with cutting them in quarters to let them cook quicker.  This is my new favorite veggie.

I have eaten brussel sprouts before but never prepared them.  I am so glad I came upon this recipe.  I also did further research on how to prepared them and found that creating a slit at the end will help them cook evenly. Delish!  I like brussel sprouts, but hadn't found an easy and simple way to make them that added some flavor while keeping them savory vs. sweet. I cut the sprouts in half and roasted at 400 for 15 minutes (shaking the pan every 5 min.) and then down to 350 for 5 more minutes and they were perfect.  Easy and yummy - I'm looking forward to leftovers tonight!
