text:
A-. Very good. For ease, I also parboiled for approx 3-5 minutes beforehand to ensure tenderness. I also mixed in some cayenne pepper in the salt/black pepper mix for a kick but only a little bit. And also roasted with big chunks of white onion sliced, potatoes (fingerlings sliced small) and chunks of carrots. Very good and at 375 degrees for about 40 mins, cooks all at about the same time. Yummers!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
First, a disclaimer, I am a habitual snitcher.... I taste everything in the various stages of preparedness (except brownie batter - I go straight to the batter with a BIG spoon, no "snitching" there). So I put the sprouts - mine were exceptionally large, so I quartered them - in the bag with the oil and seasonings.  Then I tasted.  oh, they were sooo good!  I probably ate a good third of them like that.  They were sweet and salty and I love the flavor of good EVOO. Then I cooked them.  My 8-yo son said they tasted better cooked (I had made all the kids try them raw, they were so good), but he didn't eat more than the one; my 6-yo daughter and I liked them better raw; my 3-yo girl threw them up both ways, and dh wouldn't touch them at all. So my final rating is, good recipe, just don't cook them!---------edit: I have changed my mind.  This is the BEST way to eat brussel sprouts.  There is just no comparison.  Except, I stand by my admonition to just eat them raw.  I have been making a quart ziploc of these every week, and snack on them through the day - they get better the longer they sit in the marinade; I eat them for dinner when the rest of family is having carrot or cucumber sticks; 2 of my children snitch them out of the fridge when I am not looking.  And if I really want to cook them, so the rest of the family will eat them, they are already marinated.  All around, a happy happy recipe :)

text:
The last time I had Brussels Sprouts was about 25 years ago. I was little and my Mom told me they tasted like candy. They didn't. Fast forward 25 years later. I'm on an elimination diet and in the 'it's OK to eat me' list is Brussels Sprouts. I decided to try this recipe based on the reviews of others (especially those who thought they hated Brussels Sprouts).  The recipe is OK. There was only a faint taste of the sprouts - that's because they were close to incinerated. I took someone else's suggestion and halved them and only roasted them for 30 minutes. They tasted just like the onions that get burned when I do a roast. They tasted over roasted and undistinguishable.  Meh - won't make this again. And no, these didn't taste like candy either.

text:
When I was a kid I hated brussels sprouts, but I LOVED these!!  I made about 1/2 the recipe for the two of us.  I didn't use nearly as much oil, maybe  1/2 T. and that was plenty.  Lots of course salt and seasoned pepper.  And I also added a clove of minced garlic.  I roasted mine for about 35 minutes, shaking the pan every 10 minutes.  WONDERFUL!!

text:
I can't remember how I stumbled upon this recipe, but I sure am glad I did!  This is is one of the easiest and tastiest recipes I've found in a long time.  JAQATAC is correct - they taste a bit sweet and salty at the same time!  I honestly think I could eat the entire dish in one sitting.  They're that good.  (I have 4 pounds of them roasting in the oven as we speak, because they've been requested for a family get-together!)  Throw all the misconceptions about Brussels sprouts out the window and give this recipe a try.  This certainly puts the frozen Brussels sprouts to shame.

text:
I have always been a bit leery of brussel sprouts...since it was the holiday season, I decided to give them a shot. We parboiled the brussel sprouts after removing any yellowish or loose leaves for 2 minutes, tossed them in a ziploc with the rest of ingredients and then onto a cookie sheet. Added some chopped garlic to them as well. Cooked 25 minutes at 400 F. Tasted good and my husband who loves brussel sprouts said these were the best he'd ever had!

text:
I have never had brussels sprouts before (my family never liked them) but this recipe was simple and fantastic!  I want to eat these all of the time.  Letting them brown gave them a sort of steak-ish flavor with a delicious buttery center.  I just threw a bag of the frozen sprouts on a pan and mixed some chopped garlic and the oil/salt on the pan with my hands and mixed them up every few minutes as the directions state.  I even cooked mine for less time (I just wanted some browned parts, not completely blackened).  Perfect!

I make these all the time. I roast them at a much higher temperature though about 450. It depends on if you use fresh ones or frozen and the size. Right now fresh ones are too expensive so I use frozen ones.

text:
Makes for tasty sprouts!  Halved the sprouts because they were large, which caused them to cook much quicker and become a bit crispy (I like them that way, though others may not).  I think 30 min. is definitely sufficient.  I also added in some garlic powder into the mixture.  Didn't have kosher salt, but table salt seemed to do the trick.

text:
If a few leaves come loose while you're trimming, shake and bake them with the rest!  If you've ever had the Crispy Spinach at China Grill in NYC, they become the brussels sprouts version. hummm...

Boiling for a few minutes worked great and it only took about 25 minutes to roast.  

And all the stuff you could add!  Prosciutto
Pine nuts
Balsamic vinegar
Parmesan
Garlic halves (add 7-10 min before finishing the roast)

Very good. I added freshly ground black pepper and cayenne pepper (my boyfriend and I like spicy foods) and kept to the recipe.  It was very good, the center was creamy.  I used frozen brussel sprouts, but I made sure to steam them for 5 minutes prior to following the recipe.  I didn't need to cut them in half as they appear to shrink somewhat during the cooking process.  Also, I'm a huge fan of the toaster oven and used that--they were very, very good!

userID:
1452636
Display Name:
TUNISIANSWIFE
isPro:
False
followersCount:
141
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
431
favoritesCount:
411
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/933710.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love brussels sprouts any way, shape, or form, but this takes them to a new level.  Really other than steamed or boiled, what is there to do with them?  I must also say that I had some brussels sprouts that most folks would have tossed in the garbage.  The leaves had yellowed, and I'm sure they would have been too unappetizing if steamed.  It's true, the browner, the better. The outside leaves kind of tasted like potato chips.  lol  That salty, crunchy taste was delicious, yet they are so creamy soft and sweet on the inside.  I used a little less EVOO and they were fine.  Just remember to shake every 5 min or so.  I didn't bother putting them in a bag.  Just threw them in the pan, added the salt and fresh cracked pepper, drizzled with the EVOO and shook them around to coat.  Couldn't be any easier to make and I could eat them like popcorn!  (or potato chips)  Thanks for this great recipe.

text:
I just recently started eating brussel sprouts because hubby loves them and this is the second recipe I tried. The first one was pretty good, but these are delicious! I served them along side stuffed pork loin chops and received rave reviews!
I do think I over cooked them just a little, as I took the midpoint on cook time. My oven has a mind of its own so at times it's hard to judge! 
I initially contemplated adding some garlic or other seasonings but am glad I didn't. This recipe was great just as is!
This has definatly earned a spot in our favorite recipe file!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the only way I make brussel sprouts. Sometimes, if I am in a time crunch, I put them under the broiler (just be careful to go sparingly on the olive oil) instead of in the oven. In the broiler, it only takes 10 minutes at most. Also, near the end of the cooking time, I throw some pine nuts in with them. This toasts the pine nuts nicely and adds a nice extra nutty flavor.

userID:
832014
Display Name:
MAINEMOM
isPro:
False
followersCount:
30
followingCount:

madeRecipesCount:
38
favoritesCount:
570
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/121.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made these for our Thanksgiving family potluck and they were delicious, but did make a few changes, combining them with another roasted brussel sprouts recipe I found in WW magazine. I added a chopped onion, and ended up using more olive oil than called for to prevent them from getting too dry. My other recipe suggested adding some chicken broth to keep them moist, which I'll try next time to keep the oil content down. They took at least the full 45 mins, and I did end up turning the heat down some. It is vital to stir them often, but they roasted nicely on my Pampered Chef stoneware pan -- no sticking at all. The onion was a nice addition as it carmelized along with the brussel sprouts. All in all, turned out great --not pretty, but had a wonderful smoky, mild sweetness, much more mellow than simply steaming or boiling them. They were a big hit, esp. w/my husband. Will definitely make them again.

text:
I was making brats for my son for dinner and I made the brussels sprouts, along with seasoned fries, as the sides for my son. The fries called for a 450 oven for 30 mins total, so I put the brussels sprouts on the lower rack and the fries on the upper rack. The sheet pan for the fries protected the sprouts from becoming burned, although there were a few charred pieces, which adds so much to the yumminess of this recipe. My 17-yr-old son ate them up! I made the recipe exactly (except for the temperature) and added a little garlic powder, too. So good!

text:
This is the second time I tried this recipe. The brussel sprouts are overcooked but otherwise very tasty. In this era of planetary disasters waiting to happen, I swamped the ziplock bag for a large bowl. Just add the same ingredients and toss the sprouts around a little. The end result is the same and you won't have a dirty single use plastic bag that can only be put in the landfill! Please try this and change the recipe to eliminate the plastic bag! Thank you

Last night I had some leftover smoked, nova style salmon that I needed to use up. Popped it all in the oven and roasted per the recipe instructions.  Was so totally awesome.

text:
Great, however, unless you want them to be Chernobyl Sprouts you gonna need to back off on that 45 minutes at 400F!  It only takes 20 to 25 minutes to get them to a nice toasty brown and well done condition.  Changes I made in addition to the time at temp was to slice them in half and add some parmesan cheese after coating them with EVO and some melted butter.  They are a great side dish with steaks, crab cakes, you name it.

Yes! This was REALLY good and exactly what I was looking for. My mom use to make something similar growing up and I’ve been trying to find a recipe that was a replica. This tastes just like it! Other than that, this one is a keeper!!

text:
I don’t know what people were saying about it coming out mushy and burnt. I cooked them at 400 for 31 minutes and shook them around about 15 minutes in and they turned out perfect. Also I threw some chopped onion coated in oil and did what another reviewer suggested and sprinkled minced garlic over the top. They came out Just a little golden brown but not too much and the texture was amazing not too crunchy and not mushy at all. Thanks for this great recipe

I did not have the Brussels covered the first 8 min and then when got it out of the oven noticed it looked very dry. I covered with the foil and baked covered for the rest of the time. The taste was amazing!

text:
I made this recipe using fresh brussel sprouts and I trimmed off the ends and took off the ugly parts of the lettuce. I put it in a gallon bag with some kosher salt, pepper and roasted garlic and let it sit for about an hour or two then I slapped it in an 9 by 13 pan at 400 degrees added a little bit more kosher salt and cooked it / recipe. It came out perfect tasty we loved it we are spicy people so we added cayenne pepper while the Sprout's were resting in the bag waiting to be roasted. They turned out perfect this is a great recipe and it's in my favorites so I know that we will be using it again and again. Thank you very much!

text:
Way too salty! I had bought HUGE Brussel Sprouts (each one the size of your palm) found this recipe and decided to give it a shot. I quartered them and put them in the bag with the oil, S&P and some garlic. Cooked them for about 30 minutes. When I read to shake them every 5-7 minutes I was flabbergasted! That's not easy, especially with my particular health problems. So I just turned them about 3 times. I did taste the sweet and salty right off - but the salty was overpowering. I may try again with a lot less salt and some parmesan cheese as was suggested on here. Also might try the 425 for 15 minutes as also was suggested.

text:
I love brussels sprouts...hence the 5 stars.  I made the recipe with 1 tblsp of olive oil for 1# of brussels sprouts; then used an EVOO spray for a little extra coating, some ground sea salt and no pepper.  Were fine for me as I didn't want all the extra oil. Yum!  Also, roasted the discarded leaves as another person mentioned; loved the crunchy bits.  After roasting for about 35 minutes at 400 degrees (in my toaster oven!) I squeezed some lemon on top.  I will definitely be making these again, easy and tasty.

text:
turned out yummy.... I used frozen bag of sprouts. Just opened bag, poured in olive oil, sprinkled some garlic salt and pepper, and shake, shake, shake. Then poured out on to baking pan. Spaced them out because if they are to close they will steam and turn mushy. While in oven I turned them every few min so the sides could crisp. And voila!  serve... to a happy family.

text:
I'd never had Brussels sprouts in my life until recently. I can only assume my parents/grandparents didn't like them, but I like them very much! This is the first recipe I tried and it was pretty good! Sometimes simple is best! I cut them in half and roasted them at the called for temp for 30 minutes and they were just barely too overdone for me. I like the char, but this was a bit too much. Maybe 25 min? I don't want to have to monkey with the temp during cooking. After they came out I thought they lacked something so I added a touch of lemon pepper. I will be making these again.

This recipe was really good! The first time I made it it was perfect! The second time it came out too bland and in my opinion a bit too burnt. Ironically, the second time I followed the directions better, and it turned out, in my opinion, worse. The one thing that I changed in both of them was that I coated the brussels sprouts with the olive oil and salt and pepper with a brush instead of throwing them all in the bag and mixing them that way, and they turned out fine. It was a lot less messy too!

Loved it!!! Only ever had Brussels sprouts one other time and hated them. This recipe popped up on the main feed and I thought they looked so yummy!! I saw the high reviews and just had to give it a try. Well my husband and I both loved them and can’t wait to make again. Followed the recipe exactly and mine turned out browned in spots and the loose leaves that had fallen off were blackened. Loooved the crispy black leaves! Idk why people complain and say this is too long to cook them. Mine weren’t completely brown or black. They were perfectly roasted. Will make many times!

text:
Loved these! I had a bag of frozen brussels sprouts and looked at the instructions on how to cook them. I always do the same thing, stovetop, so I thought I'd try the oven roasting. Mine were already in the oven when I came across this recipe, and it's the same! I just added garlic powder with the salt and pepper. I probably roasted them for about 35-40 min to get the nice browning. SO delicious this way! I like to have them with a little good quality balsamic vinegar on the side. This may just be my new favorite way of cooking brussels sprouts!

text:
I’ve had roasted sprouts before and liked them, but these were better!  I’m sure it was the plastic bag massage that made the difference. Like kale chips they benefited from having the oil, salt and pepper eased into the leaves, and a split sprout has all those wonderful nooks and crannies. It didn’t take mine quite as long as suggested here to get them to that crunchy dark brown crispness, but like anything else, you just have to watch them as you do the turning. And they really ARE better when they get that dark.

text:
OK I made this just as the recipe described. I love steamed Brussel Sprouts and thought I tried this as something different. I cooked the sprouts in the oven until they had a brownish almost slightly burnt look as some of the pictures look. The sprouts were cooked, a little squishy , which I didn't mind. But I think the sprouts were over-cooked according to the recipe. If I tried this over again I would par-boil first then brown a little in the oven. Some people commented on making the sprouts turn black, I'd didn't like it that well done.

userID:
16553587
Display Name:
Kimberly Richerson Stevens
isPro:
False
followersCount:
5
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
10
favoritesCount:
361
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2661205.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I was very skeptical. I've eaten one Brussels sprout in my life and thought I was going to die before I got it chewed enough to swallow. Ok, maybe I'm exaggerating slightly. I started out by only using a half pound. Still used the same amount of olive oil and seasoned to taste with pink himalayan salt and pepper. I didn't have kosher salt and I'm not fond of it. Convection baked at 375°for 10 minutes then turned the sprouts over. (I halved the larger ones before baking also) then baked for another 5 minutes and sampled one. I think I might just like them now. I'm personally not fond of the burnt taste of the leaves that had fallen off so I didn't bake the sprouts any longer. I posted a pic for reference. The sprouts have a nice dark brownness where they lay on the pan. The inside is not mushy but is tender. There is that sweetness all are posting about and nutty flavor. A slight cabbage flavor but not prominently noticeable. So, all in all, I am glad I tried this. I believe everyone has their own liking of doneness. If you're trying this for the first time, start small. Taste the sprouts as they're cooking. You be the judge on when there done. After all, YOU are the one eating them & know what you or your family likes. Like many have done, I am going to try different seasonings & maybe some parmesan.
Review:
Rating:
1
dateLastModified:
2017-10-15T02:17:11.147
helpfulCount:

I halved them then par boiled them with the kosher salt for 7 minutes. Shocked them in cold water. Next I shook the oil, pepper and a touch more of kosher salt mixture with the sprouts. Finally, put them on a cookie sheet and placing in a preheated oven at 425 for 20 minutes.
I've never had this vegetable and I plan on keeping this recipe with my changes of course.

I cut them in half and that worked well.  Popped them in the oven when I pulled the turkey so the timing works well (like to wrap the bird and let it sit for an hour). I wanted to add a sprinkle of lemon juice but forgot. Next time. Everyone loved them. Great recipe. Thanx

text:
SUPER easy recipe that is very flavorful. I'd suggest cutting the sprouts in half for slightly faster cook times (also, the oil gets down into the nooks and crannies this way...delicious). I do cook at a lower temp (350) for this reason. I will also adjust the time depending on how many I'm cooking. Basically, start the "poke" test after 15-20 minutes (everyone has their own preferred level of doneness).

text:
Made these for last night's dinner, and they were great! I did the mixture, popped them in the oven for 15 minutes, flipped them and did another 15, and then pulled the brussel sprouts out, added a bit of Parmesan cheese (1/4 cup) on top, and then put it back in for another 5 minutes to let the cheese melt. My dad loves brussel sprouts and these blew him away!!I tweaked the recipe by adding a bit of red pepper and more black pepper, along with the Parmesan cheese. However next time, will replace kosher salt with sea salt, it was a little salty for my taste.

text:
Yum!  I never used to like brussels sprouts, but I'm coming around the more I try them. This was a very simple way to prepare them.  I hate mushy vegetables, so I took the advice of someone who said to roast at 425 for 15 minutes. That sounded about right to me, and it was!  I noticed that the smaller sprouts were perfection all the way through while the larger ones were more firm in the middle. In the future I'd try to buy them of a more uniform size, though it wasn't that big a problem. I used a good quality olive oil and a coarse sea salt, which gave them a nice little crunch here and there.

Definitely a new favorite.  I halved the sprouts, didn't trim up the bottoms, brushed the bottom of the pan with olive oil as well and put the face down.  With them halved, it cut back on the roasting time - I did 20 minutes at 400 and turned it up to 425 for 5-10 minutes.

text:
These turned out perfect! I followed the recipe. Since I was using a countertop convection oven, I had to reduce the heat down to 350 pretty quick, and they reached the desired deep brown color in about 35 minutes. The recipe does say to reduce the heat as needed, so I don't think of that as a change. Even my husband, who dislikes vegetables as a rule, admitted that he never thought he would ever say he liked Brussels Sprouts, but after trying this dish he enjoyed it!

text:
I'm not a huge brussel sprout person but decided to give this a try, and I loved them. They were a huge hit and didn't last very long. I took the suggestion to add some garlic and it added a great flavour. I left them whole and cooked them at 375 for about 25mins. Shaking them every 5 mins or so. They were still a bit crunchy but yet soft. Oh and to the person that said to leave the little leaves in that fall off....that was a great call. People were fighting to get the little crispy leaves. I will definitely make these again.

A big bone of contention to the folks putting these recipes together. I HATE plastic bags and those who use them for one use and then throw into the landfill. How about placing everything into a large mixing bowl and then TOSS gently! I've read numerous recipes and they ALL suggest using a "sealable plastic bag" to mix the ingredients. Please, just use a mixing bowl! OR keep ONE plastic bag in a drawer JUST for this purpose.

text:
I made a half cookie sheet of the brussels sprouts & the other half with carrots.  I mixed both veggies with EVOO, salt & pepper on the pan, plus added a generous amount of minced garlic.  I kept each vegetable on separate sides of the pan but baked the two together.  I cooked them 25 minutes when they were tender and roasted so the brussels sprouts were dark on the outside.  I will be making this recipe again, thanks.

text:
So delicious!!!  I have been wanting to make roasted brussel sprouts for a few years now and this Thanksgiving I finally did it.  I used very expensive extra virgin olive oil, kosher salt, and Italian seasonings.  When finished, they have a slightly sweet, nutty, and slightly salty taste.  Very different taste than when they are steamed.  The brussel sprouts turned out so good that my daughter asked me to roast a second batch that she would take in her "care package" back to university.  Do not deprive yourselves.  Make this recipe!

text:
Yum - very popular with the kids!  Our were done in about 30 minutes.  Increased heat to 425 the last 10 minutes, as it was baking with something else, and that was probably a bad idea as they blackened much more quickly once the heat went up, and I wasn't watching them closely.  400 the entire time is probably the way to go.  Try sea salt or kosher next time, as I just used regular, and that flavor kind of got lost.

text:
I added tiny pieces of garlic and a squeeze of fresh lemon. I roasted them at 375 for half an hour on a strip of foil. They looked just like the ones pictured -- nicely browned but not burned. The amount of salt required in the recipe is a bit much, I think. Oddly, I missed the sweet taste mentioned by others. I felt a bit of sugar might have enhanced the dish. I will not make them again because my husband ( who has never liked brussel sprouts) hated them.

We are lucky enough to live in a town that closes two blocks of Main Street every Sunday  ten months of each year for the local farmers market. You get to hand pick your own product before purchasing . This recipe is a snap when the sprouts are all the same size and shape. Buying bagged produce is a -shoot....Frozen is marginally better. As for this recipe, I do cut the sprouts in half and shake the pan every five minutes or so until the y reach desired degree of blackness is reached. Otherwise I pretty much follow this recipe.

I have made this recipe for my family more than 5 times. Once you put your sprouts into the 1 gallon ziplock bag with oil, sprinkle salt, pepper and lots of  mccormicks Montreal Steak seasoning. Shake and cook for 40 mins. PERFECTION!!!!!!

you can do this on a stove top as well. I heat olive oil and throw brussel sprouts in and add 1/4 cup water and put a lid on. When the water is all evaporated, i open the lid and lower the heat and cook through-shaking the pan to prevent sticking or burning.. Done in 15 minutes. Add salt and pepper at the end. ;)

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've never been a huge fan of sprouts unless my wife cooked them in a pound of bacon - because, bacon. 

I wanted to find some method that would yield edible sprouts without all the fat. I saw this one and the huge amount of ratings and was like, wow, that looks too easy to be that good. Well, guess what - it was  good!

I made sure to cut away most of the base (I heard that makes them bitter) and cut them in half. Also heard not to exclude any of the misc leaves that fell off, that they would make very tasty crunchy bits. Oh boy, did they!

Came out so good, my wife and two young ones (6,7) loved them! I did cook them at 425 for 15 minutes and they were perfect. Also added a few cloves of crushed garlic. So good.  Only giving it a 4 because of the alterations.

text:
I think this is the same way these are prepared at Whole Foods. I often go during lunch and get a half pound of these to eat at my desk at work. When I make them at home, I just cut them in half, spray the bottom of a baking sheet with olive oil cooking spray, then top the sprouts with more spray, and good salt, then bake at like 375 for about 20 minutes. A little lighter with the spray, but either way these are a delicious way to get in something super healthy.

text:
Delicious!  I used a 12 oz package of brussels sprouts and drizzled them with Tuscan herb infused olive oil just enough to lightly coat then sprinkled kosher salt. They only took 20-25 minutes in my convection oven on 350.  Olive oil and salt work like magic to bring out the flavors in vegetables.  I prepare most of my vegetables as above or in a saute pan. Don't overcook - vegetables are best tender but crisp.

text:
Excellent and simple recipe! I had medium to large brussels sprouts, so cut them in half first ,and then baked at 375 for 30 minutes in a convention oven, tossing occasionally. Turned out brown and crispy on the outside, soft on the inside. Next time I will reduce the salt a tad, and toss everything in a casserole dish inside of using a plastic bag (the plastic bag did a good job but seemed wasteful). userID:
2229026
Display Name:
Charlene1234
isPro:
False
followersCount:
22

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2308291.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made this recipe dozens of times.  But I make one small change... I blanch them first.  I also like to cut them in half if some are really large, you want them to all cook at the same speed.   I never thought I'd like brussel sprouts, but I tried them roasted and they're fantastic.   I like to blanch them for a few minutes first, before roasting.  (I don't like them crunchy inside - but I love them roasted and just turning brown... or even a bit brown on the outside).  The little brown crunchy pieces left over in the pan are like delicious little chips that are irresistible!   And left-over sprouts are just as good and I can make a meal out of them!!  Lots of people who say they don't like brussel sprouts end up liking them prepared this way.  

I like to roast all my veggies this way now!!  Small baby potatoes are fantastic this way.  Asparagus is as well, but I don't blanch either one.  Blanching the sprouts helps to remove the bitterness in the center if it's not cooked all the way through.  Make sure you lay foil down on the pan and spray it with cooking spray.  Then don't forget to stir them half way through.  This is a great way to do veggies!!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2015-11-24T11:38:48.31

text:
I am absolutely amazed at how good these brussels sprouts came out. The only ingredient I changed was instead of kosher salt I used garlic salt. I also halved them and roasted them face down for 40 minutes - I never once shook the pan or moved them at all and they came out absolutely amazing. Definitely worth waiting until they're really browned. Oh! And all the leaves that fell off came out amazing! I wish I hadn't thrown out most of the fallen leaves because those, while burnt looking, came out tasting unbelievably good. Can't wait to make these again.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I feel foolish admitting this, but I have been calling them Brussel sprouts (LOL). If nothing else, I did learn that Brussels is plural, and more awkward to say followed by "sprouts".

This recipe is basically what I use for any vegetables that I roast, and I roast a lot, so it wasn't anything unique in that regard. I had never made Brussels sprouts before, and I really don't know why.  Prepping them was the hardest part, and I ended up cutting them all in half after trimming . I don't use a plastic bag, just throw them in a bowl and mix everything together. I also roasted these at 350 (using convection roast setting on my oven) for approximately 30 minutes. They were cooked nicely as well as very tasty. This is a great way to roast almost any vegetable!

text:
This is my go-to recipe for Brussels sprouts. Instead of sticking them in a ziplock bag, I put olive oil on the baking sheet, put the Brussels sprouts on it, shake up the tray to get the olive oil on all sides of the Brussels sprouts, then topped with salt and pepper. Turns out just as tummy and you don't have to mess with an oily ziploc bag.

This came out really good!  I had frozen sprouts do I let them defrost. I took them out of the bag and added the olive oil to the bag (just one tbsp since I only had 12 oz of sprouts).  Next I mixed the salt,pepper and added a pinch of red pepper.  I added these to the bag with the sprouts and shook then baked as directed.  We will make again for sure!

country:
None
text:
I make these all the time either for myself or for guests. As others suggest, cook them at a bit lower of a temperature and cook them until they're brown and a bit crispy. You won't regret it. All of the bitterness goes away after the long roasting process. I also cut mine in half, as suggested. Just salt, pepper, and olive oil is all you need to bring out the nutty sweetness of the sprouts. Enjoy!

I'm not a big salt fan (and rarely add it to my food after the fact), but to me 1 teaspoon was not enough, but I didn't have any kosher salt (or know what it was for that matter) so I used sea salt. But, all in all I would probably cook them again. 

Update: 10/25/15 I now add fresh minced garlic and I can't stop eating them!!!

text:
After reading the reviews I chose to roast for only 30 min. They turned out great...I ate them like candy! Although, I believe they would of tasted even better the full length that the original recipe recommends. I think the key to this recipe is making sure you stir/shake the sprouts every 7-10 minutes. They are easy to make but do require attention. Really tasty and easy recipe thanks for sharing!!

text:
OMG these were absolutely AMAZING!!!!!  I now love Brussels sprouts and can't wait to make them again.

I used frozen because it's all I had.  I thawed them, halved them (read reviews and didn't want them soggy) Put them in a bag, drizzled olive oil, sprinked just a BIT of salt and garlic powder, and baked as directed.  My boyfriend and I RAVED over them.  I never thought I'd crave Brussels sprouts, but these changed my mind.  I had them as a side dish but I could easily eat them as a meal by themselves.

Make these, you won't be sorry!

country:

text:
**EDIT:  I've made these again and again and have found that covering the halved spouts with tinfoil and cooking them at 450 degrees on the very top rack for 20 minutes, give them a little shake, and back in the oven uncovered on the top rack for another 10 minutes makes perfectly cooked, carmalized spouts!! I also cut the oil down to about 2 tbsps. EDIT**


I made this as directed and I did not end up with delicious caramelized nuggets :(  Mine were dry and not tender (or maybe not fully cooked) on the inside.  I did cut the spouts in half as many suggested.  I might make this again and take the advise of another to smoosh the spouts toward the end of cooking to separate them and allow them to completely roast, not just the outer leaves.  Thanks for the post!

text:
WOW! What a simple yet delicious way to prepare Brussels sprouts.  I will FOREVER prepare them this way.  I did make a few alterations:  washed, trimmed and halved sprouts AND used home grown broccoli then sprinkled 1 tsp of sea salt over both and let sit for approx. 10 mins.  Then placed in a large bowl and put in olive oil, ground pepper, and minced garlic- about 3 cloves.  Put on a foil-lined pan and baked for approx. 25-30 mins.  Sooooo..... good!!!

text:
Just made this. I love Brussels sprouts so I'll pretty much like any cooking method. 
Not sure why others say cook for 15 mins. I halved the sprouts yet still cooked for 35 mins and some were still a little crunchy. 
This recipe was ok. I'd probably cook them like this again as it's easy, but it wouldn't be my preferred method. Shortly steaming, then sauteeing with bacon and red wine vinegar is much tastier.

text:
delicious. I too parboiled the trimmed brussels sprouts for 2-3 minutes, quick drain/shake to remove majority of water. Then I added them to a bowl with oil, peppered&seasoned salt, tossed the sprouts until coated, put them in the broiler pan in the oven, added maybe 1/8 teaspoon of kosher salt on top before baking 20 minutes on 350. I stirred, increased temp of oven to 400F, baked for about 10 more minutes. perfect! And still the beautiful bright green due to the parboiling. Easy recipe you can walk away from and not worry about burning or stirring every 5 minutes.

text:
Always hated Brussels sprouts until I had them roasted with OJ. Try adding 2-3 TBL frozen orange concentrate to this recipe. Yummmm! You will have to shake them and check them for burning (the sugar in the OJ will burn and blacken). Also try covering with aluminum foil for 20 min or so and then uncover the rest of the time for browning.

userID:
4714372
Display Name:
peachlovehope
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
18
favoritesCount:
45
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674147.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My husband and I liked these better than sauteeing them with minced garlic. I had a bad experience eating brussel sprouts that had been cooked for hours in a stew (=really, really unpleasant taste/texture). I haven't bothered trying them since. My husband grew up eating them & enjoyed them so I finally mustered the courage to try them again. First we tried sauteeing them with garlic, and it was okay, but I wasn't able to eat more than one. I tried this recipe- I cooked them for about 12 minutes at 375, then lowered it to 325 (worried they may burn without cooking the inside), but after my total cooking time had been about 25 minutes and they were very firm in the center, I upped the temp to 375 again and after a total cook time of about 35 minutes they were done. I did NOT cook them to a dark brown/black. I cooked them until they were a nice brown (more than golden) on at least 2 sides (I was shaking the pan every 10 minutes). They were very good. The little leaves that had fallen off & blackened had a very strong tasted & a crunch. I could see how this taste may be appealing on the entire batch, but it would have been overpowering in my opinion, which is why I chose not to cook the whole batch to that color. I was very happy with how they turned out and ate about a dozen of them. The inside was soft enough to be enjoyable, but definitely not mush. I think the key to this recipe will be finding just the right temp and time for each family's tastes. Will make it again!

I loved this concept! But I did add a few things as they just seemed to fit! I added 5 slices of bacon, but up in bite sized pieces, 8oz Crimini Mushrooms and about 2-1/2 tsp of minced garlic and a 1/4c of parmesan cheee. And added everything else that the poster of this recipe added. Cooked at 400 for 30 mins, turning veggies about every 5-7 mins, getting them to the slightly brown, with a hint of black stage. They were yummy!!!

text:
It was too salty for me.  I usually omit or halve salt from recipes but I was scared this time...I mean everyone is supposed to hate brussel sprouts, right?  Still, I was pleasantly surprised!  I will make this again the next time I find them on sale. I was scared of the creamy/mushy middles and halved mine.  I wish I had not.  The larger halves were the tastiest.  The combination of creamy and robust/nutty was the best.  I also added a clove of garlic as many reviewers suggested and was pleased with that.  Several people suggested removing the choke.  Upon google image searching I discovered it was bigger than I would have guessed so search it yourself or do a good strong V cut in it.  Mine looked like Pac-man :-)

text:
I detest Brussels sprouts.  This recipe made them edible and enjoyable, to a point. The darker the outside, the better, for those of us who do not like Brussels sprouts.  I place mine on a rack and don't bother with shaking the pan, because I'm lazy.  I'm so pleased I tried this recipe. Thank you for posting it.  Replace oil with garlic butter, or garlic oil for a different flavor.  Be sure whatever you add can take the heat, I'm not sure any herbs would work, for example.  One could toss them into an herb butter afterwards, and parm cheese, for example.

I have nothing to compare this recipe because I have never had brussel sprouts...I prepared them with chopped garlic and sprinkled parmesan cheese along with sea salt, and roasted for 20 minutes in a 425 degree oven (as another reviewer suggested)...There was no odorous smell as other reviewers stated. The sprouts turned out well, I think...much like little cabbages with a nice salty caramelized coat....the burnt-like shavings that fall off are like chips...yummy...Very easy side dish!

text:
I decided to be a grown up and try brussel sprouts using this recipe. I didn't love them, but I didn't hate them either. The main reason I won't be making brussel sprouts again is because I didn't care for the way they made my house smell for two days! 

Like one of the other reviewers, I cut the sprouts in half before roasting.  This cut down on the baking time by about 15 minutes, and it helped to brown the bottoms.

text:
Thank you for the recipe, I've never gotten these right before & it's an excellent base recipe. Per reviews I halved the sprouts & blanched for 2 min. in water w/ Lawry's seasoned salt, before roasting added 2 cloves of chopped garlic & a small onion sliced thin, roasted 20 min. I have never seen my 1 year old son eat so many vegetables & am floored that Brussels sprouts are what he finally picked to chow down on!

Holy smokes, was this recipe great! I can remember slimy, stinky boiled Brussels sprouts as a kid...it has probably been 30 years since I ventured to try them. But desperation for more veggie options that my kids will eat led me here. SO easy, and SO yummy! Only changes I made was to use garlic infused olive oil, because that's what I had on hand, and add a half of a small onion, sliced thinly. I love them, the lids loved them...so, there you go!  My daughter even helped cook them, and has claimed these as her new "specialty"!

text:
I never liked Brussels Sprouts until I tried this recipe. They are now my favorite vegetable! This is so easy and so flavorful. When cooking for two I cut back to 10 to 12 Brussels Sprouts, 2 Tbsp. olive oil, 1/2 tsp. regular salt or sea salt, and 1/4 to 1/2 tsp. coarsely ground black pepper and roast for 30 minutes in preheated oven, turning every 5 to 7 minutes with a tongs.

text:
Everyone always cringes at the sound of the word "brussels sprouts!"  So, I had to try them! I decided to try several new recipes for our Christmas dinner...and these were a BIG HIT with everyone! ...even my 8 and 11 year olds loved them and had seconds!  I added parmesan cheese to them (after baking), and ended up only turning them 1 time, during the 35 min that they baked. I followed the advice of an on-line chef - after you cut them in  half, put a slit (1/4inch or so) in the stem. This helps the stem cook more evenly, since it's thicker than the rest of the little cabbage).  Bon Appetite!

I'd never tried Brussels sprouts before this recipe, and oh my GOD am i a convert. These have become my favorite vegetable and i can eat pounds of them. I've since tried them prepared other ways and while they're still good, this is the absolute best.
 After having prepared them according to this recipe a few times, i found i really enjoy adding garlic salt after they've roasted. Also, i like to cut the larger ones in half to get more carmelized surface area. These are in the oven right now, for the umpteenth time since i discovered this recipe two years ago, and i cannot _wait_.
SO DELICIOUS.

Have made this recipe many times,always add some minced garlic-and when I want to kick it up a notch- I add sliced almonds for the last 5 or 6 minutes, and toss with 1 tablespoon Balsamic vinegar,1 teaspoon lemon juice and lemon zest just before serving. I don't really rely on the cooking times in the recipe as it depends on what I'm roasting in the oven for dinner and adapt the time for that temp. Every time I make these, I buy more sprouts per person and still never manage to have any leftovers!!

text:
The only way I'd ever eaten brussels sprouts was swimming in cheese sauce. Alas, health needs have dictated that we find another way to enjoy them! So I thought this would be a nice beginning place, and it was!  My oven was too hot, so the outer leaves got too toasted, but inside, yummy!  We'll do this again, because there was no bitterness, just good flavor!  I might add some other spices or herbs to it next time, for variation. But I'm really shocked that someone would give a bad review without trying it first. Not cool.

text:
My first time eating and cooking brussels sprouts and it turned great! I cut them all in half before cooking just to make it easier to cook. I cooked them for 30 minutes and some parts turned out almost burnt - but I think I liked it that way. I threw in any leftover green leaves that fell off and they turned into crispy chips in the end, which was a nice extra surprise. They were all pretty salty but that I was my own fault since I didn't account for the fact that I had less brussels sprouts than the recipe called for. I will be making this again for sure!

region:

country:
None
text:
Several of the reviews I read were from people who previously didn't care too much for Brussels sprouts but were a fan of this recipe.  I can understand that because I thought that roasting them gave them a mellower taste, so by all means, try this recipe if you're not already a big fan of Brussels sprouts.  However, I am in the other camp of people that absolutely LOVES the stronger tang of steamed Brussels sprouts with a drizzle of butter and a sprinkle of salt.  That will remain my go-to method.

asilann

country:
None
text:
I read another review that kicked it up to 425 for 15 minutes and started there. I ended up going for 25 minutes because I wanted mine more brown. I used sea salt instead of kosher. And I used basil infused olive oil instead of standard olive oil. And this was just awesome! I actually started cutting the Brussels because I was going to initially pan fry them. But In the midst of doing that I found this recipe. So half of my Brussels sprouts were cut into lengthwise quarters. And what I found out was that the leaves, when separated from the sprout, tasted like chips! So awesome. This was very good. I would do this again and again!!

text:
I very much enjoyed this recipe and so did my husband. I was actually very nervous because I did as others had suggested and read all the worst reviews as well as the really good ones. I think it's just a matter of taste. The Kosher salt is a must! Do not forget to rotate them so they darken on all sides. They are mushy on the inside which I wasn't use to but like I said, I very much enjoyed it. I will be making this again. My husband really loved the texture and the flavour. He said the darken leaves were very enjoyable. On another note, I did not leave them in the oven for 45 minutes. In fact, they were pretty much done after about 20 minutes. I think Dark brown is the idea colour and not black.  But in summary, AWESOME

text:
I enjoyed this as written but I found whole sprouts bitter. So the second time I made it I cut off the ends, cut in half and took out the core (with the tip of a vegetable peeler). Watch them so they are just brown with a little black, it's easy to overbake these. Also I found 1 tsp salt way too much, so I cut it to 1/2 tsp. I love cooking fresh vegetables and I am already planning on making these again.

text:
I have, over many decades, choked down the brussel sprout dishes people swore I would adore.  Sorry... My genetics make me taste that bitter vial flavor that their tongues seem unable to sense.

I got a bag of veggies... it included about 25 sprouts.  I didnt want to be an  so I looked for a recipe and tried this one.  Fully expecting to want to die, I tried one..... then another... then another....

Are they my favorite thing in the world?  No, but, WOW.... simple, healthy and I ENJOYED it.  So much so that I _may_ buy sprouts again...  Either way, I DO know how I am going to "help out in the kitchen" next time I see somebody about to make a vial brussel sprout casserole -- 30 minutes with me and that will be the best casserole in the world :-)....

p.s.  I did use 2-3x the pepper recommended and would do that again.

p.p.s.  when you make it, make sure there are several or more lose leaves.... the "brussel sprout chips" are really good.

text:
I couldn't make it the way this is stated. I am greatful for the idea. I did what the recipe called for ingredients wise but changed it up for my taste. I layered brussels in a bowl that I cut in 1/2. With each layer I sprinkled (good) EVOO and Kohser salt and fresh pepper. When I was done with that I gave it a good folding so I was sure every little gem had something on it, at that point, plastic wrap  over the bowl and into the frig for a couple of hrs. When I baked them I put them face down on cookie sheet lined with foil for 20 min. at the same temp on the recipe. For my taste they were excellent BUT even better the next couple of days. Also, a little freshly graded parmesan was delish!

text:
i grew up hating brussels sprouts. seriously hating them. my husband finally talked me into tasting roasted brussels sprouts at a local resaraunt. OMG that was heaven, tried to get that at home. this is the clostest. i did 3 things different
1. cut them in 1/2 lengthwise, put flat side down first
2. add parmesan cheese to the sea or kosher salt and oil blend
3. cook 20 min or until browned to your liking then turn over for 20 more or till done. 
groovey!

text:
45 minutes! Only reason to cook them so long is if you are cooking something else for a long time.
Cut them in half and roast at 425 for 15 minutes, stirring every 4-5 minutes.  Toss with more olive oil and some lemon juice and for heat some crushed red pepper.
Optionally-- sprinkle with lots of sweet paprika before roasting.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/69415.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Yummy!  We've always microwaved brussels sprouts before, but if I'll definitely do it this way in the future if I have the time :)  I used frozen ones, let them thaw part way (would have let them thaw all the way if I'd had time!), and cut the bigger ones in half.  Roasted them for about 35 minutes.  They didn't get super dark brown in that time, but the rest of dinner was ready and they were kind of browned.  One random one actually had a crispy brown leaf.  My fiance got that one and said it was good, but he thought it would be overwhelming if they were all like that.  He liked the whole ones best, while I preferred the halved ones- the insides were so creamy, like other reviewers described.  Definitely going to make this one frequently!

text:
Bf and I somehow managed to make it through life without trying brussel sprouts.  Ever.  He decided to buy some at Costco the other night, though, so I had to figure out some way of making them.  RE to the rescue!  I got some recommendations on this recipe so I figured I'd give it a shot.  Brussel sprouts are a pain to trim, or at least they were for me.  I got advice on that to, so I removed the green outer leaves, cut off the stem, and cut into the bottom like a cross hair.  Then I proceeded with the recipe.  Final verdict:  bf really likes them.  I'm not so thrilled.  They weren't bitter, which is what I was afraid of (I don't like bitter at all), but they just reminded me of baby cabbages.  They were kind of chewy and soft--not my thing.  Since bf was a fan, though, I'm rating it based on what he thought.  Doesn't seem like I'd be a huge fan of these no matter how they are cooked, simply bc they don't seem to be my thing.  He added salt to them, so the kosher salt wasn't really enough, and I agree.  I even added garlic powder but I think they need a tad more seasoning to be 5 stars for the bf.  Thanks for the recipe!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this recipe last night for my fiance and I. We both loved it. He doesn't typically enjoy brussel sprouts and was pleasantly surprised. Me- I couldn't stop eating them before our other food was finished. What a nice flavor, crispy outside and softer/savory inside. I did cut them in half and roast them that way- giving a very nice roast/crisp to them, which we enjoy (and probably cut back on cooking time). Do be sure to turn them every 5-10 minutes for a more even cook. I used sea salt instead of kosher. I know my boss makes a variation of these stove top too. She cuts them, cooks in pan with spices (tarragon, etc.) then steams in same pot until done- and still ends with a nice crisp to them. Enjoy this super-easy recipe and share with all brussel sprout skeptics!

text:
I hated, hated, hated brussels sprouts growing up. My dad would boil them-yuck! Finally, after 20 years of rebellion, I decided to give them another try! I am so glad I did. I did make some changes to this recipe-first, I cut the sprouts in half and took off half the leaves to have more darkened, crunchy pieces. I then doused them in salt, olive oil and 3 TBSP of chopped garlic, threw them on a baking pan and roasted for 30 minutes or so, turning them 2-3 times during cooking. Delish!

I have never had brussels sprouts but bought them on a whim today. Knowing the bad rap that they have and that people say they taste like cabbage, which I dislike, I was very nervous about this recipe. I was pleasantly surprised at how delicious these are though!  Super yummy!  I added about a clove and a half of garlic and a little sliver of butter and halved them so they would cook better, as some suggested.  Definitely a keeper and I don't think I'll try them any other way!

text:
First time ever with brussels sprouts - some of the outside leaves that fell off where awesome when I took them off the pan, but the sprouts themselves, not so much. No really sure what people are talking about when they say the inside was creamy - not on mine. Cooked them for 30 minutes and they were starting to get rather dark, so I believe they were cooked long enough. My neighbor said I should have scored the bottoms, if, and thats a big if, I try them again I will score to see if the insides get cooked a bit more. My kids wouldn't eat them, and my hubby, who loves veggies, left some on the plate.

This was my first time attempting to cook a brussel sprout. I will admit to not trying them due to their bad reputation. We followed the recipe, but added a bit of minced garlic and then roasted them on the grill in a foil packet.  They were delicious. We will definately be making these again. They were a bit black and crunchy on the outside, but the inside was soft and reminded me of cooked cauliflower.   Great method, made our family brussel sprout eaters! Thanks!

I totally messed up and accidentally put one TABLESPOON of kosher salt instead of one TEASPOON. To balance this, I added some garlic, a tiny bit of white wine and less then have a lemon of lemon juice. It turned out better than I thought it would, considering my dumb mistake. After 45 minutes they still weren't blackened, but I took them out anyway. Next time I make them I'm going to do it strictly by the recipe and see how I do. Though they came out tasty and my boyfriend actually loved them. He wants me to make them the same way again. I'm just curious as to if they'll be better done the right way.

I love eating brussel sprouts this way.  As recommended by others, I chopped my brussel sprouts in half before roasting with some roasted garlic-flavored olive oil.  I also checked on them every 6-8 minutes and shook them around so they would crisp up nicely on the outside.  Fantastic.

text:
I only gave this 5 stars because there wasn't a 10 star option!  I am addicted to these.  I make them at least twice a week.  One thing I do differently though.  I can't seem to find the small sprouts, so I cut them into halves and for the really big ones I quarter them.  I cook them at a 350 to get them tender and them I turn up the heat at the end because I LOVE the little crispy leaves.  By far my favorite veggie recipe.

text:
This recipe is SO good!  I made this for Thanksgiving dinner.  My sister, who is somewhat of a gourmet cook, LOVED the way these brussel sprouts turned out.  The guys did not care too muck for them but all the women loved them.  I prepared this exactly as written, no changes.  I let them cook for approximately 25-30 minutes in the oven until mostly blackened.  I was a bit skeptical until I tasted them.  If you want a bit of gourmet, then this is the recipe for you!! SO simple and easy!

First time trying brussel sprouts! I've now made them twice in two weeks using this recipe. The best part for me was the crispy random leaves that cooked with  it so I think next time I'll go one step further and maybe cut the sprouts in half and loosen up the leaves. Tasty and very simple recipe!

I liked these, but wasn't really convinced until I added just a squeeze of lemon juice after removing from the oven.  It really added a little zip that was missing.  And those other reviewers were right - those "burnt" looking leave were pretty tasty!  I sampled one right out of the oven and it tasted like a fresh, crisp potato chip of all things!  Unfortunately they didn't stay crisp once I served them, but still tasted good.  I halved my somewhat smallish sprouts and since I had something else in the oven, baked them at 350 for 30 minutes and they were perfectly done.

I love brussels sprouts and have had them many ways.  I just picked up 2lbs. of fresh ones at my local Costco today and wanted to try a new recipe.  I'm so happy I tried this one!  This is a keeper and not only delicious but quick and so easy to do. text:
Delicious!  I roast most of my vegetables now.  This just proves how the flavors are enhanced by roasting.  More dimension than just boiling.  Just check on your brussel sprouts after 15 minutes.  If you don't like them too brown, take them out sooner. My husband likes them barely cooked and I like them really roasted so I take out half at 15 minutes and leave the rest in for another 15 minutes.
